author: Brad Brown

text:
‚Äã¬†@Brad Brown¬† Umm no, I think you are just severely underestimating the amount of food involved in raising a cow. It takes 24 to 49 pounds of plant material to make 1 pound of beef. The animal "wastes" most of what they eat just to live, so most of the energy and nutrients invested are not accesible to us.
If people ate more plants and less meat, there would be less incentive to breed and raise animals that need feeding and therefore fewer crops needed. It is physically impossible to add more layers to the trophic chain and expect to have a more efficient system.

text:
Today marks 6 months without meat for me, too :) I haven't felt a craving for meat itself in a long time, but there are some dishes I miss where there's no real substitute for it. That being said, I enjoy food much more nowadays. With meat it was easy and quick to just throw some lazy, bland dish together and call it a day. Going vegetarian breathed new life into my cooking. 

I also reduced my dairy consumption significantly and am currently in the process of going strictly vegan every other week. Might take a long time before I get comfortable with the idea of getting rid of dairy completely. 
Wishing you the best of luck, thank you for not watching idly as our world burns down :)

text:
Can we own up to the fact that 100 gas, mining, and large scale agricultural companies are responsible for well over two thirds of the negative impact on our planet? Individuals cutting down on meat, recycling, and driving an electric car will make a dent on that impact. But switching to renewable energy is the thing that's REALLY going to make a difference. Not you doing Meatless Mondays. 
I totally advocate cutting down on animal products for health, climate, and even ethical reasons (whatever makes sense to you). In some places, people eat WAY too much animal, and not enough plant food sources. I know it's hard for me to travel to certain places cause it's so hard to find vegan or vegetarian options at restaurants and hotels that aren't green salad. So I'm glad to see that it's becoming more mainstream, compelling places to provide more choices.
author: Lindiwe Ngwevela

text: ¬†@barmiro¬† For me personally its really easy to change diet but I know for most people its a lot harder. I went from low-carb(2 years), vegetarian(6 months) to vegan(5.5 months so far). Your body will hate when you increase your fiber intake and it will take some time to adapt obviously, its best to start eating more fiber early on and doing a gradual change. I basically changed my diets in 1 day to another so my tummy was a wreck for like 1 month.

text: While all this is correct and good, the problem is, based off of the stats provided by the blokes at UC Davis, only 24-25% of climate carbon emissions can be traced to food. Massive, yes, but there are bigger issues too. And even in the case of the food industry there are problems. I‚Äôm of course referring to the companies themselves. Studies have found that 71% of all emissions are emitted by just 100 companies. 100. While it‚Äôs all well and good for people to take an active role in helping the planet, what isn‚Äôt good is contributing to the idea that it‚Äôs just our responsibility as individuals. Blame falls moreso on corporations, and if we‚Äôre going to combat climate change we need to combat said corporations more than we need to change our diets. Again, this isn‚Äôt to say diet reform is bad, moreso that it ignores the root of the problem.

text:
Always think of farting animals but no-one thinks of farting people. If you're going to eat beans, you're going to replace the cows. 
   Other things make an enormous amount of methane too, like concrete. No-one thinks of that. 
The difference between cows and cereal crops is the amount of damage crops do to the soil and the water they use, not to mention the thousands of tons of pesticides, fertilizers, fungicides etc. that is used and the fuel the machinery uses to turn the soil etc. No, none of this has even been considered.
   Now lets get to the health angle. Cereal is nothing compared to meat and fish. One cubic inch of steak has more nutrients in it than a full box of Corn Flakes. 
    How much do you need to eat in a day of this stuff compared to meat. Meat is necessary only once a day, that's all. Just one small meal. Don't believe? Compare how much meat is in the supermarket with the rest of the shelves.

text: How does plastic pollution change global temperature?
author: Jack Ward

text: ¬†@Jack Ward¬† it doesn't - at least not directly - but it does change the climate: mass death of sealife, ocean pollution, etc.
author: Renewable Revell

text: ¬†@Renewable Revell¬† I mean global warming seems much more of an issue. It will also lead to warming of the oceans and massive wildlife loss
author: Jack Ward

text: ¬†@Jack Ward¬† while being distinct, global warming and climate change are practically interconnected. Plastic in the oceans kills sealife, which in turn limits biodiversity, which in turn has the ultimate effect of warming the planet (seeing as oceans are the lungs of the planet, converting Co2 to oxygen - we need our oceans alive). My initial point was that cutting out meat but still eating fish is not enough, because the majority of plastic pollution in the oceans is from discarded fishing materials
author: Renewable Revell

text: ¬†@Renewable Revell¬† I mean they are kinda the same thing. Global warming effects all climates
author: Jack Ward

text: ¬†@Jack Ward¬† they're interconnected and part of the same issue but not entirely the same. Climate change could refer to a number of phenomena, i.e. depletion of natural habitats and animal extinction, air pollution, bleaching of coral reefs, deforestation... But global warming refers specifically to increasing global temperatures from emitting greenhouse gases. Either way, adopting a vegan diet is the  single biggest thing a person can do, starting today, to prevent climate breakdown
author: Renewable Revell

text: People also need to know that it‚Äôs affordable to have a plant based diet. Lots of people think it‚Äôs only something you can do if you have money. But rice, beans, lentils, and tofu (if you have access to them) are extremely cheap foods that are really good for you, have a high caloric density and lots of protein. I‚Äôve been vegetarian on a budget for over a decade. Expensive vegan cheeses and meat alternatives aren‚Äôt even a part of many plant-based eater‚Äôs diets. In fact many of us talk down on these foods for being a waste of money and unhealthy. All I have to do is walk by the meat aisle in the grocery store to see how much money I‚Äôm saving by choosing other protein sources.

text: I love this, but the amount is showing CO2 per serving... Not per Calories. I see this all the time. You mention eating a serving of lentils having virtually no CO2 produced, but they also have next to no Calories. Meaning, you'll have to eat more servings veggies to get the same number of Calories from a serving of beef. Depending on the cut of beef, 4 oz of ribeye would be the equivalent of 10 cups of steamed broccoli in calories. (This varies by source and fattiness of ribeye) Still likely lower Carbon overall, but not nearly as much as you initially implied. It would still add up to a mind blowing amount if we all ate better for our bodies and the planet. Obviously vegetables produce less CO2 per Calorie, but I would like to see how big the difference actually is.
author: Wesley

text: Humans will never learn. We keep looking for how we can change our diet or use renewable energy or whatever to fight climate change. These things can make small impacts, but the only thing that will TRULY make a difference is stabilizing our population, maybe even reducing it through having fewer children. Our Earth has finite space and resources. It still takes SPACE to grow vegetables. It takes SPACE to create housing for new people. That SPACE that we take steals space from wild plant and animal species, worsening our biodiversity crisis. And with more an more people we will have a need for more and more food. More and more water. It's simple. We must control our population while at the same time investing in environmentally friendly initiatives. Otherwise, we're doomed no matter what. And we'll take all the animals with us. And I haven't even started on how some bodies just don't do well without meat. I eat meat only a few times a week, but I cannot go 100 percent animal free. I get sick. It just doesn't work because of my DNA.

text: Regenerative agriculture is the only solution. It's not meat vs vegan/vegetarian - it needs to be changing how we farm. Even the food you eat on a vegan/vegetarian diet is being farmed wrong and has negative impacts on our environment (yes, still better than factory farming animals). We have very limited harvests left with traditional tilling and farming. We need regenerative agriculture - that needs to be our priority. Regenerative agriculture and land use practices naturally sequester a critical mass of CO2 in the soil and forest, and restore healthy soil

text: I really like this video because I've been a vegetarian for years (almost all my life actually) and have been striving to go vegan more and more with each meal... but what I love about this video, is the mentioning of the Mediterranean style diet. I have so many friends, even ones who work in conservation, who care deeply about the environment but just can't give up meat. Putting more of an emphasis on reducing intake instead of having absolute zero meat intake is more encouraging to those who eat meat and don't want to stop entirely. Any changes made, however small they may seem, are actually great changes if everyone makes this one change collectively. I'm striving to go vegan because I have no desire to eat meat, but if you just want to eat less meat than before then that's amazing and I'm so thankful you're doing your part too üíó We need to support everyone who is trying to make a difference in their own way.

text: ¬†@Leo¬† I don't think being vegan  caused your brain fog. It sounds more like an Omega-3 deficiency, which has nothing to do with being vegan. Brain fog is a common symptom of an Omega-3 deficiency. Omega-3's are essential fatty acids that help support brain function. Non vegans rely on sea animals to get their source of Omega-3's. However, Omega-3's are not produced by animals. They are produced by algae, which is how the sea animals get their essential fatty acids. Some people think that eating things like chia seeds and walnuts is enough to get Omega-3's but that's not true. Those plant sources only contain ALA. ALA can convert into the other two fatty acids DHA and EPA, however that's assuming one gets enough ALA and that you are not consuming too much Omega-6. Because this ALA conversion is unreliable, it is important for a vegan to take an algae based Omega-3 supplement unless they are living in Asia and are consuming sea vegetables on a daily basis. People on a vegan diet who are experiencing brain fog really need to start paying attention to their Omega-3 intake. It's not the vegan diet itself rather than the lack of education and information when it comes to nutrition.
author: Angelisa Sapon

text: ¬†@Angelisa Sapon¬† I was taking an algal omega 3 supplement, and was using algal oil in cooking and consuming lots of chia seeds. And even so, fact is, it has a very low absorption rate and you have to consume so much of that stuff to get enough on a vegan diet. My parents had a TV show about nutrition before I was born, so I'm very well versed on the nuances. Fact is, I wasn't getting enough protein and didn't feel satisfied. Some people can make it work, and it feels good for a bit, but after nearly 5 years of strict veganism, it definitely caught up with me. I feel a lot better now. text: I hope that everyone knows that global temperature began to rise after 1980, after being stable for 55 years, and that's also when beef consumption plummeted. So, giving up meat won't make much of a dent, if any difference at all, in global temps. What is the real cause of this post-1980 rise in global temperatures? A major cause is the ever-increasing electricity demand from computer industry, which was beginning to take over our economy in 1980, just when the temps began to rise from increased CO2 from coal-burning power plants. The computer industry's insatiable appetite for electricity, which is projected to rise uncontrollably, as the industry automates the entire world, has also spawned fracking, which is the real cause of the recent spike in methane (not cattle!). Also, the destruction of the rain forest needs to be focused on, and Brazil has plowed up its rangeland to grow harmful sugar, so the rain forest is destroyed to create rangeland for their cattle. So, instead of giving up a very nourishing and essential (for many nutrients) food like meat, give up non-nourishing, indigestible, harmful, and rain forest-destroying crops, like sugar cane, chocolate, coffee, tea, wheat made into refined flour, soybeans, corn (corn oil and high fructose corn syrup), canola, sugar beets, palm oil, cotton grown for very unhealthy oil, crops grown for alcohol, marijuana, cocaine, and tobacco. Then, a huge amount of land would be freed up to pasture animals, so we can become healthy again, and to finally regenerate soil that has been destroyed by cultivation, which will enable carbon storage in the soil, the best strategy to deal with CO2 in the atmosphere. Also, let's put a hefty environmental tax on the computer industry's use of electricity, so they can finally pay for the environmental devastation that they have played a large role in, which will fund the renewable energy industry that computers require.
author: Joan Tendler

text: How many people know what the Mediterranean diet actually looks like? I wouldn't be surprised to find that a lot of people are just as unfamiliar with that as they are a vegan or plant-based diet. For personal health, I'd say the Mediterranean diet is probably the best and most studied but having tried at various points throughout my life to eat that way, I can also say it's not that easy. It requires cooking almost all your food yourself, as well as planning your oily fish intake carefully to meet Omega needs while making sure you're sourcing fish responsibly and with the right levels of Omegas. The people who eat a traditional Mediterranian diet, come from family and community units that are vastly different from the majority of the US for example. Small farming communities where women are responsible for cooking and meal planning, making sure that everyone is well-fed and keeping food waste to a minimum. It may seem like the less controversial suggestion but in practice, it feels a lot more like saying "don't worry too much, just have a go, we know you probably won't do it anyway". That's not really good enough when we've also been told that eating vegan is the thing we can do that has the single biggest impact on climate. It's also increasingly compatible with the lives of more people living in urban environments who work long hours. There is, of course, planning involved but based on my own experience as someone who lives in a major city, a lot less planning than the Mediterranean diet.
author: Edie Lee

text: I‚Äôve felt so much lighter and looking better since I switched to a mostly plant-based diet several months ago. I still enjoy meat every once in awhile, mostly on the weekends. It‚Äôs nice to know it‚Äôs having a positive environmental impact too!

text:
Thanks for telling me what foods to avoid. I'm going to go on a diet with the sole intent of causing climate change.
Population too high? Hurricanes'll clean that up real fast. Deforestation got you down? Most trees love tropical temperatures and a significant increase in carbon dioxide will mean significantly more air for plants to breathe. Want to move to Alaska but it's too cold? Make it a little warmer. Nobody likes city life in the heat, and so global warming will prevent or at least slow down urban sprawl. Developing nations and coastal cities produce most the toxic pollution in our air and oceans, and it just so happens that those two forms of society will be hindered the most by rising sea levels and increasing temperatures.

People, for these facts and more please look into regenerative agriculture. text:
Just so you know, ren; these diets have a very high rate of desistance. Mostly for social reason but health reasons make up over 1/4 of the reasons why people quit. If you ever feel like you are being pressured to put your health at risk for some arbitrary sense of morality, just know there are millions of others who felt the same thing and that it is possible to quit before you hurt yourself. There is a ex-diet community somewhere waiting for you if you ever need help transitioning out or if you feel like the veggie community is being way too extreme. 

Just know you aren‚Äôt alone if you ever feel abused by them. Because anyone who makes you feel less is actually a lesser person than you.

author: Ian Wilson

text: It's also important to consider how each person's financial and medical position factors into this. Depending on where you are and where your food is coming from, particularly your meat can restrict your diet. If you come from a low-income household, and cannot fund a vegetarian, or even Mediterranean lifestyle, that's important to take into account. Fast food restaurants make meat easy, cheap, and filling, perfect for low-income people. If you medically need some of the nutrients found most commonly in meat, such as if your body doesn't process magnesium correctly, so you have to have more than the average person just to actually receive what you actually need, then meat is a great option, especially in places like the USA where healthcare is often too expensive to be a realistic method. I'm not advocating against not eating meat, I myself am a vegetarian for the reason of how wasteful meat is, but it's important to take into account that everyone has different factors affecting their diet.
author: Sully Johnstone

text: ¬†@lif3andthings¬† Why yes it does. The reality is people have to eat, and a large portion of what we farm goes to feeding livestock. Cut back on the meat you eat, and you cut back on the harm caused by farming. Almost nothing in the world is without consequences, but sometimes we can choose the option with lesser consequences, because not only is the harm caused by eating less or no meat better than the harm caused by eating meat, but it also means the resulting problems you mentioned (polluting waterways, erosion of topsoil) is easier to manage, because less farming overall means less of those problems to correct for.

text:
¬†@TalanSouthway¬† 
If accounted by weight, yes, animal consume around 80% of crop yield by weight.
If I account for sole consumption, nope.

Take corn n soya for eg.
Around 30% of corn cobs directly go to livestock, rest 70-80% goes to human consumption, for making high fructose corn syrup, ethanol, and small part for direct consumption. The left over is fed to livestock.
For soya, nearly all of it goes to human consumption, most of it for soyabean oil.
What is left is soya meal. It isn't suitable for humans to eat, so is fed to livestock.

Earlier, these animals relied on grass. After industrial revolution, they were fed these leftovers, as industrialists figured it out, they can feed it to livestock , instead of burning piles of it.
If we didn't have livestock, we would have ended up with huge piles of leftovers being burnt down.

While I eat meat very infrequently compared to most, I am moving to cut back more and more over time and this becomes increasingly easier as local supermarkets and cafes etc continue to stock more and more vegan options. But I whole heartedly agree, that even if you and the family have just started doing one day a week without meat, that‚Äôs better than nothing, fully acknowledging that it should not be your end goal and neither will it be the solution to climate change etc.

text: I get all of the benefits of going vegan- but for a lot of people it‚Äôs just not a sustainable lifestyle health wise. I went vegetarian for a few years, and was planning on going vegan, but I saw a massive reduction in my energy levels by removing meat, despite making sure I was eating enough and taking supplements where I needed. There are quite a few people who simply cannot absorb nutrients (such as iron and B12) well enough from supplements or plant based alternatives & I was one of them. I wound up anemic and dangerously fatigued. I‚Äôm happy that this video isn‚Äôt simply telling people to go vegan, like some of the comments are. I wish so badly I could be vegan, but for my body it‚Äôs simply not possible and I think a lot of the vegan community tends to see that as an excuse or not trying hard enough when it‚Äôs not. I know there are a lot of people like me out there, so providing ways for us to reduce our carbon footprint whilst still eating meat was really great. Thanks !

text: When you think about it: is the earth more compatible with: [A.] animals (that have existed since the beginning alongside humans on earth) or [B.] pollution-causing tech, that involve highly toxic chemicals from production/manufacturing to break down? Humans need a lifestyle change, yes. But focus on what is actually foreign to most of human history. Our ancestors didn‚Äôt need cars. Why do we? Why can't everything be walking distance? If this is really about cooperating with the planet...we should use what is organically of the planet and not synthetically produced/fabricated. The industrial revolution may have made things convenient, but mass (over) production, mass depleting the earth of resources, over consumption, is the problem. Our human limitations that tire us out help keep the balance from over stripping the environment. We shouldn‚Äôt override that with pollution-causing tech. We need to slow down. Faster isn‚Äôt actually better‚Äîwhether it‚Äôs fast/convenient food or fast/convenient transport.

text:
Everyone says, OMGAWD I don't know how you're vegan, I could never do it. When in reality, you can. It's not that hard, you just have to do research and experiment with different vegan foods. It takes a little extra effort, but it's worth it in the long run. I lost weight at first because of the diet change. That encouraged me to workout, and I've been losing weight and getting fit. I feel refreshed, and full. My body odor doesn't smell as bad as it used too, and my feet don't smell as bad as they used too. I only get acne on some of my periods(also cause of my skin type). I'm helping the environment(both through my diet, and I volunteer, recycle, reduce my waste, and I don't buy plastic). I'm also saving animals(through my diet, and I volunteer). It really does open your mind. I even tried meditation, which has helped my anxiety so much. Being vegan opened my mind into trying new things, and taught me to be more accepting and not give up because "it's too hard." It really does help. Stop telling yourself I can't, and try telling yourself I can try. Or maybe I'll give it a shot. It'll boost your self confidence too, because you proved to yourself that you can do something you thought you'd never be able to do. Have faith in yourselfüíû 
If you are going vegan. Or trying to, do your research. You can still be vegan and not get nutrients, or be unhealthy üíûTake care of yourself and have a nice dayüíû

text: Don't feel like giving up meat? Try another shopping alternative: don't buy anything in plastic. I started doing this several months ago and it was so easy to do, saves money, and is often healthier. Bring your own containers and buy in bulk. You'll begin to realize how much of what we eat comes coated in plastic (ice cream, Goldfish, dairy and non-dairy milks). This helps avoid packaging and materials that cannot be recycled (which produce a lot of emissions just to be made and more when they are incinerated). Seems too intimidating? Try one simple switch at a time. Stop buying packaged milk and buy oats in bulk to make super cheap and easy oat milk at home. Craving something sweet? Nix the packaged cookies and bring your own container to the bulk section to fill up on chocolate almonds. If we all did one switch as small as this the planet will notice. Have a nice day!

text:
This is a little disturbing. A couple of things. First, cow carbon is from plants and they get it from the air, whereas fossil fuel carbon would stay underground for millions of years if we did not intervene. There's a massive difference: fast carbon cycle vs long-term carbon cycle. You'll notice that almost all the studies cited only look at emissions but fail to mention the net addition of carbon gases to the atmosphere. The source of the carbon matters. Second, did the video mention a study but fail to provide a citation/link anywhere? 

There are many, many reasons for us all to eat less meat but just looking at emissions of global warming gases from livestock and equating those with emissions from fossil fuel burning -- as Ben Houlton does here -- is not a reasonable thing to do. On this basis, why do we not fret about the emissions of 7.2 Billion humans? The answer, again, is that like the cows we are part of the fast carbon cycle, not the geological one.

text:
Are you an idiot or just stupid? As we all learned in science class, weather is the short-term variation in the atmosphere--the temperature and precipitation TODAY--while climate is the averages of all those things over a much longer period of time. Climatologists prove climate change by looking at the differences we are seeing in the Earth's climate, and we see that it's changing at an alarming rate. That's how we know climate change is real. Meteorologists getting your forecast wrong today has nothing to do with it. Furthermore, your steak, which, as we learned from the video above, contributed to the production of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, thus contributing to climate change, will cause an increase in extreme weather. In terms of hurricanes, remember, warm temperatures in the ocean cause hurricanes, so warmer than average temperatures for a longer period of time will cause more frequent and more extreme hurricanes.

Also, your anecdotal evidence of your own chickens polluting more than your own cows on your small farm, means nothing. We are talking about massive factory farms here.

text: We need to move away from this narrative that individual consumer choices are the way to combat climate change. People make decisions based on what's available, they don't always act in perfectly rational ways, and when averaged across all humans, the trend in human behavior is always toward ease and comfort. The vast majority of climate change can be traced back to the supply side: corporations that produce that meat, use carbon-intensive manufacturing processes, and continue to expand fossil fuel extraction over clean energy sources. Even if I and every person I've ever met stopped driving entirely, gave up on meat, and installed solar panels on our homes, it would make basically no difference on the world's carbon emissions. Even if I quit my job to become a transient, wandering around and convincing every new person I met to do the same, I'd probably max out at around 100,000 people. If all of those people also started living the life of an ascetic monk, it still would make very little difference when compared to the 7 billion humans, and it would take me another 5 decades to do. We don't have 5 decades to fix this.

text: It takes 660 gallons of water to create one 1/4 lbs. hamburger and 2,500 gallons to create one pound of ground beef. Agriculture accounts for 55% of all water usage in the US. By contrast, domestic use accounts for about 5%. A 2009 Worldwatch report found that livestock account for 51% of all greenhouse gas emissions compared to about 20% that account for all transportation modes combined. It is estimated that 1 acre of Brazilian rainforest land is cleared every minute. The vast majority of that land cleared is then used for grazing to sustain the worlds rise in meat consumption. Meat consumption is by far the biggest issue we face when dealing with climate change but there is just too much money to be made off the industry so this information is often buried. There is a great documentary on Netflix that lays out facts and figures of "sustainable" livestock farming. It is called "Cowspiracy".

Please try not eating animals and animal secretions - you will find it surprisingly easy especially after educating yourself. Youtube is filled with recipes to veganize your favorite dishes and other videos about how to go vegan.
author: AnimalsAre BeautifulPeople

text:
¬†@AnimalsAre BeautifulPeople¬† Dominion is exactly what made me want to go vegan having seen it a couple weeks ago. Before that I saw game changers which interested me in at least reducing meat intake for both my health and the environment but after seeing Dominion (well the first 40 minutes couldn't get past that tbh) the only meat I'll eat is either meat a friend hunted themselves or fish I fished, and even then it's probably only gonna be if I need the protein boost and fall on hard times where I can't keep affording plant based meat replacements like tofu tempeh and chickpea flour where I wouldn't afford store bought meat either anyway.

With all that being said I have to agree that it's better to encourage people to reduce meat intake by having meals at least once or twice a week incorporating a meat replacement and a dairy replacement as well if they're a milk drinker, while also educating them with facts about the environmental and ethical issues with the animal agriculture industry, leaning heavily into the environmental concerns as well as health concerns though careful not to blow the latter out of proportion or else you might lose credibility with them, namely because well lets be honest most people are painfully and disturbingly selfish. Show them how it might effect them or their children in the future and they will care much than they will about suffering kept out of sight and out of mind behind the factories walls. And it's also quite possibly a gateway into them becoming more and more willing to embrace at least a mostly plant based diet and lifestyle. As I try more meat free meals I find it harder and harder to justify eating meat ever where before I started I figured I'd have no trouble getting a steak with friends if we went to a steakhouse. The same would go for the average carnist too I'm sure, you see not only the issues with it but also that not only is there an alternative but it's one well within your grasp the idea of cutting out meat and dairy entirely or at least mostly doesn't seem so radical anymore.

So colonise Venus then. A balloon filled with normal breathing air naturally floats 50kms above the surface of Venus where the conditions are near earth like (same as in a car parked in the sun) add some helium to the balloon & it rises another 2kms up where conditions are the same as Hawaii, so no reason we can't colonise.

Now in saying that, the tech we would use there to become self sufficient & build a habitat would be the same as we would need to build an artificial island on earth, so there's no reason we can't just do that instead, especially for the people of counties like Kiribati that are drowning with rising sealevels caused by our overuse of non-renewables. We would be more than capable of building them some floating islands to anchor to their existing islands & setting up recycling systems that reuse urine to grow more plants, just like we'd have to on Venus, along with basic levels of chemical fertilisers as inputs for farmland, either soil or hydroponic based. Once we get that working, we have access to 70% more space on earth. No reason we can't gift these people with some islands as experiments into obtaining fully self sufficient communities

We could also start caring for grasslands that have huge productivity potential but are currently mostly desertifying due to poor management or destruction of native animals/eco-systems & then desertion by humans

we could also just fund birth control of any type as chosen by the woman, for anyone in the world that wants it, along with basic health care & food for their children, because this is proven to stabilise populations, that as soon as their children show they will survive to adulthood & birth control is available, women choose to use it & have only 2 children each average

or we could just declare war on someone & kill off large numbers of the population that way......

text:
The opposite's actually better, because chickens are mono-gastrics & so compete with us for food, while cows can eat grass that we can't use (chickens are better than grain fed cows, but grass fed ones are best). 
Lab meat IF it ever happened would need to use cropland to produce all the proteins/amino acids found in meat, then separate them all out individually so they can be added to the growth formula at the correct ratios for the finished product, so it's actually not efficient, but add to that that all lab meat startups have been stuck at the same point for years now, they cannot remove "fetal bovine serum" from the growth formula & have it still work to produce meat. Google that if you want to really see the truth :( Everything they're doing is just for funding & PR but there's no genuine signs they're ever going to get anywhere, but they cover that by claiming "trade secrets" as the reason they can't give information as to how their progress is going, truth is it's simply not going, there's no genuine evidence to suggest otherwise from any of them, hasn't been for years.

Insects are actually the most efficient source of meat & will always remain far more efficient than lab meat

& I'm totally with you on the vegans! Their diets are actually really inefficient too when you look at them properly, but they seem to think that if they scream loud enough & often enough, they will con people into thinking otherwise (including themselves)

author: Knowledge Is Key

text:
¬†@Knowledge Is Key¬† google "fetal bovine serum lab meat" for info on it, typing that into google scholar gives more comprehensive info on what's going on too, along with more details on the processes involved in making the lab meat.
You can also look at all the various press reports from the start up companies & year after year see them claiming that they will be releasing the product commercially by the end of ....(whichever year the report is writen in, or sometimes the following year). I saw one the other day for example from a vegan boasting about "just inc" & linking to stories on them, that company claimed they were going to have lab meat chicken on the shelves by the end of 2018 & that they had a plant based growth serum, but more research shows no evidence to support their claims of the plant based growth serum, but lots of investment money after that vegan food company announced that they had "been secretly working on lab meat for 2 years & were close to being able to release it commercially" prior to a funds drive. That's a typical presentation for all of them, repeats over & over & over. 

They can certainly all make lab meat, they put into the test tube/petri dish the stem cells of what they want to grow, all the amino acids that are found in the final product, sugars to feed the reaction & then the active parts of the unborn cow blood to actually cause those stem cells to interact with the amino acids in a way that combines them & over time it becomes "meat" I personally do plant tissue cultures as a hobby & this is a very similar process & easy to see how it works & that it does, in plants, same thing, you can take a part of a plant, a few cells is enough, put it into a test tube/petri dish, along with sugar & hydroponic fertiliser (that contains all the chemicals that will make up the grown plant) & over time it will grow into a new plant. Depending on what part of the plant you have, commonly you need to add different hormones/"plant growth regulators" as well, such as starting in GA3 to stimulate a dormant embryo to begin growing, then transferring into the same medium but with "BAP" to cause the cell mass to develop leaves, then transfer into the same medium but with "NAA" to cause the cell mass with leaves to develop roots, at all stages in the culture, the plant will grow just fine without leaves or roots, as all it's nutrients are coming directly from the medium it's growing in, being absorbed through the cell walls.

When it comes to animal based tissue culture, things get much harder, because plants have the ability to fully clone themselves, while animals don't & require extensive scientific knowledge & skills to clone, but the basics are still the same, add sugar & the animal's equivalent of that hydroponic fertiliser, then add an extra catalyst to trigger reproduction of the nondescript cells (stem cells), then trigger them to form the type of cell that you want, in this case muscle. They can actually get part of this process without fetal serums (forgotten which part now) & they use that in PR claims to state that they have achieved it without fetal serums & are "just refining the growth process" but they can't actually grow from scratch to muscle fibres in a lab without using the fetal serum. All have significantly reduced the amount of serum they need (started out at 50 litres per burger pattie) but all have reached the same point & got stuck. They mostly use cow fetal serum because it's the most available, but they can substitute it for the blood of any unborn animals for any meat growth. The most promising lead on removing the unborn animal blood appears to be using human waste product blood, with enough of it, it's possible they may even be able to use adult blood in the place of the fetal serums, potentially buying all blood products that have passed their shelf life & need to be disposed of & using those in the lab meat, after further refining. They may even be able to harvest the blood of dead humans & refine it to obtain small amounts of the components they need to grow the meat. They could do that with animals too, but that defeats the purpose of the lab meat, hence why some are looking to human waste blood to sell their product as "ethical". They all talk about making a plant based formula, but there's just no evidence they're getting anywhere on that. So yeh, the can make it, no question about that, but they need to use both stem cells and large amounts of unborn baby animal blood to do so
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
‚Äã¬†@Knowledge Is Key¬† "also what do you mean by inefficient. Environmentally, the amount of work that goes into it, what? " So the reality is that a rumen is very efficient. It can process 80kgs or so of grass or other cellulose material per day, fermenting it all & extracting from it the amino acids required for around 1kg of meat production. The rumen also comes with it's own transport system, generally referred to as legs ;) This is what typical ranches can look like https://www.google.com.au/search?q=australian+cattle+station&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjA3tPOkMfaAhXDGpQKHVZgBRAQ_AUICigB#imgrc=mGGS9nGHV4stmM: in that setting, they release those rumens on legs & let them find their own food & 12 months later, use planes to round them up again & muster them back to the station, where trucks are waiting to collect the mature ones & transport them to slaughter. They ensure that that land is scattered with small windmills & drinking water troughs so the cows can access drinking water once every 5-10kms in any direction they go, with enough water for a small number of animals to drink from. Those water points end up doubling as water sources for local wildlife too & so actually enhance the natural eco-systems rather than negatively impacting them. Other than that & the medical checks carried out each year, there's no additional work involved in producing meat based food that way, so it's dam hard for lab meat to compete with that efficiency. Each cow in that environment will need around 20 hectares of land to feed them. Lab meat needs to access the same quantities of amino acids as the cows do for growth, so while the lab meat will only need 1kg of inputs for 1kg of outputs, someone or some system is going to have to go through that 80kgs of grass & extract just the 1kg of amino acids from it to feed into the lab set up, so that's a lot of work we're now trying to do instead of letting cow rumens do for us.

In reality, that type of land wouldn't be used, much higher quality cropland would be used instead & crops like soybeans planted with mechanical equipment, harvested & processed to extract the amino acids to feed into the lab meat, so that means clearing forest land to obtain the land with enough rain to grow soybeans, using the fossil fuels to grow them & then using more energy to extract the amino acids after harvest. Those crops also need fertilising, that can be done with chemical fertilisers, or the waste from the soybeans can be somehow processed to return the nutrients from them back into the soil, currently that is done by feeding crop waste to animals, who again use their rumen to ferment it all & poop it back out in ready to use form for the plants within a day or 2. Livestock currently do this with 6 billion tonnes of dry matter per year, of which only 14% is edible to us, 46% is grass & 32% is crop waste http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/home/en/news_archive/photo/2017_Infografica_6billion.jpg so we also need to find a way to deal with that waste if we don't feed it to livestock for conversion to fertiliser. In the days before people worked out how to make cotton seed edible to cows, the way that waste was disposed of was to pile it up in fields & burn it, that's the only realistic option that would be available again if we stopped feeding it to livestock & regardless of if that organic matter is broken down in a rumen, in a lab system, in landfill or via burning, it always gives off the same methane & CO2, so we don't even reduce cow burping emissions by removing them from the equation.

So all in all, it sounds good, but in reality, nature actually has highly refined & efficient systems already in place in the form of animal rumens & we just can't realisticly compete with using them properly ie having them process only waste & grass, if we have them process grains we could eat, then that's inefficient, but used properly, it's far more efficient than we can achieve artificially. The only way we can really improve efficiency beyond that is with insects that don't waste energy on generating heat, therefore directing all amino acids in the grass & crop waste directly into meat production. The most efficient way of creating the lab meat would probably to have insects eat the waste & then processing the insects to extract the amino acids from them, so obviously it's therefore easier & more efficient just to directly eat the insects.

I've got sources on lots of the stuff I argue with vegans, but on the lab meat I haven't really saved any, because it's always changing (while still saying the same, just a year & name update) & because it comes up so easily on google. Most of the rest of what I've said is a mix of stuff I've got from lots of websites & combined, but if there's a specific element I've said that you want a source on, let me know & I might have one here for that :)

"side note: i always like it when people agree with people on youtube ü§£üëå" me too :) although I also enjoy a good debate, just as long as there's facts involved rather than the vegan ranting of propaganda & denial of anything that doesn't fit with what they want the truth to be. I've learnt a lot via youtube debates :) often learning more from those I disagree with than those I agree with

text:
Buying regional is awesome :) raising your own chickens for eggs (or insects fed on kitchen scraps if you don't have space for chickens) is great too & if you can grow your own food for plants like lettuce, that makes a huge difference, as lettuce has huge amounts of waste due to rotting & huge water needs to grow it in the first place, so any waste reduced for foods like that makes a big difference!

See what animals are killed in the protection of crops near you too. There will be massive numbers of mice, which you probably don't want to eat, but there may also be wild pigs & deer as well, if so, if you seek out & eat them, that will cause them to be humanely shot, rather than the cheaper but much crueller poisoning that's used when the meat won't be eaten. Lots of rabbits are killed to protect crops & are good to eat too, but be really careful if sourcing that, as most rabbits are farmed in horrendous conditions, so don't assume they're wild unless you actually speak to the hunter or otherwise manage to 100% confirm they are

text:
¬†@Mechanical Blurr¬† meat shipping is efficient though, plant shipping is not.

Take kangaroo meat, that's shipped to 50 different countries on the other side of the world to where it's produced.  Roos travel up to 100kms a day, can just wait for them to come into areas near the processing plant & shoot them before they eat the crops being grown for humans, with them having eaten desert grasses their whole life to grow. Intestines etc are left for scavengers, blood to feed the soil, so as to keep the eco-system intact, desired parts of the carcass are simply loaded onto a specially designed rack on the back of a ute & driven to a nearby processing centre, where carcass is checked for parasites & diseases & body temperature, then skinned, then moved into a cleanroom for cutting & packing. large slabs can be cryopacked & then refrigerated & will stay fresh for 3-6 months. When a large enough load is collected, then a refrigerated shipping container full of high calorie, high protein meat can be put on a slow cargo ship to reach it's destination in a month or so's time, where it's unloaded & sent to stores. At this point it still has a refrigerated life span of months or a frozen lifespan of a year or more. Total resources used in it's production & transport were 1 bullet, 5-10 seconds of power for a spotlight, fuel to transport to the processing centre, fuel for refrigeration form that point on & fuel for a slow moving cargo ship. That's very little! Statisticly 80% of that meat will be eaten too, whereas only 55% of fruit & vegetables will be eaten after their transport.

Beef, lamb etc have a similar production cost, but are usually transported longer distances from their farms to slaughterhouses, this is done live, so no refrigeration costs, but less efficiency in terms of transporting whole animals, so only about 15-20 tonnes of actual meat per road train, but after slaughter it will be 60 tonnes of cryopacked high calorie, high protein meat per shipping container, just like the kangaroo.

Avocados by comparison must be picked by hand, one by one, so far less efficient than meat, reach processing destination & be cooled within the same time period as kangaroo, be sprayed to prevent stem rot, be sprayed with various pesticides, depending on destination country, be washed or brushed to remove bugs & dirt, be sorted by size so they fit into packing trays correctly, have imperfect fruits found & removed & disposed of, be packed into single level trays with extensive packing materials to protect them from damage from others in the batch pressing onto them, be transported in refrigerated shipping containers, but unlike the meat, most of he shipping container is filled with packing materials & air gaps in order to protect the fruit (and half the fruit is seed that will be thrown away too, while the bones of the meat were cut out before transport) & unlike the meat with months of shelf life, the avocados have only a few weeks before they will rot, so no slow ship travelling around the world via the most efficient route, their ship must travel directly to the sales destination & packaging must be designed to only transport the immediately required supplies to the destination country & another ship must leave directly for that country 1-2 weeks later & repeat year round. There is also the risk that one or more fruits may begin ripening on route, due to an extra fruit being thrown in the batch from the ground or similar & if this happens, it will cause unexpected early ripening of the entire shipping container & cause them all to be disposed of unsold

All in all, if meat is being shipped because there is a better growing zone on the other side of the world, it can be an efficient use of resources, but fruit & veg are extremely highly demanding & inefficient transport items with huge waste levels due to such high levels of perishability & lack of adaptability to alternative storage methods such as freezing, canning, drying, smoking etc (some fruit & veg can be treated in some of those ways, but today's vegans are generally picky & demand their food fresh & refuse to eat anything processed to extend shelf life & increase efficiency of production, making them very high resource consumers!)
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
¬†@toadie¬† You also need to consider the yield/number of people that can be fed per hectare/per kilo of chemical fertiliser & rice is a big winner in these regards, making it FAR lower in greenhouse gasses produced per calorie than crops like lettuce & kale. 

Chemical fertilisers are the cause of nitrous oxide emissions & they are 300 times more potent than CO2, v methane's only 30 times higher, & nitrous oxide kills the ozone layer too! 

Low calorie yielding crops also require far more deforestation to feed the world than crops like rice do. On a starvation ration diet, 1 hectare of rice can feed over 500 people, while the primary foods in most vegan diets feed less than 1 person per hectare & use more chemical fertilisers per hectare than rice does! Without question, rice milk is FAR better for the environment than almond milk is!

Cut down on low calorie, fast rotting fruit & vegetables if you want to reduce methane & greenhouse gas emissions

text: I have thalassemia minor (a trait of the actual, deadly disease), meaning my red cell count is lower than normal. The classic choice for boosting it a bit, according to most doctors, is eating red meat. Well, I have been vegan for the past 5 years and my red cell count and b12 is on the same, if not better, levels; I am being tested every year. I have a very active lifestyle and I work out 4-5 times a week. Plus, when eating meat and dairy, I used to get sick at least once every year and since I stopped I haven't been sick even once...not even once! I am not attributing everything to veganism, but I can honestly say that all these side effects and health risks advertised by meat lovers are just uneducated bullshit. Educate yourself and you will realize that veganism is absolutely healthy, viable and inexpensive.

text: This info's actually wrong, for the environment you're better off with beef. The reason is that while beef has much worse feed conversion ratios, the food cows eat is almost completely inedible to humans, they have a rumen that means they can obtain calories from foods we can't, such as grass. Chickens are mono-gastrics & as such require grains that we could directly eat & so they directly compete with us for food, while cows are eating the grass & inedible crop wastes. That said, most chicken food is the waste that's left after soybeans have had the oil extracted to make vegetable oil for human consumption & so with that they don't compete with us for food we want to eat, but just be aware that feed conversion ratios don't tell the whole story. Cows raised in systems like holistic grazing are some of the best options for the environment, beaten only by eating the animals like wild pigs, deer & kangaroos that are killed to protect crops (and insects)

If you want methane free, kangaroos meet that need, while still eating only grass. Scientists at Australia's government science organisation (the CSIRO) tried to experiment to replicate that in cows & failed, however in the process they found & patented a seaweed that reduced methane by an average of 98-99% when fed to cows as 1% of their diet & they scientificly proved it to reduce methane by a minimum of 80%. 
Now that being said, it's a gimmick. There's no correlation, let alone causation between ruminant numbers & atmospheric methane. There's been numerous tests in history, the North American bison kill off & rinderpest virus outbreaks in Africa, killing 10% of all ruminants (wild and domestic) fail to register on ice core samples as even a glitch & there are less ruminants on the planet now than at any time in human history. Methane is a natural bi-product of organic matter breakdown, the same microbes live both in ruminant guts & in landfill & soil. If cows don't eat the grasses etc, they still give off the same methane as they breakdown, this is why landfill methane levels are so high.

The only methane that genuinely matters is the methane that's been out of the system for millions of years - the stuff from natural gas. There IS a direct correlation between natural gas getting into the atmosphere & atmospheric methane levels. Here's a bias discussion about that, but it's from a reputable soil scientist & I've failed to debunk anything she says, obviously the audience this is written for make it very bias though, but it's still interesting http://www.amazingcarbon.com/PDF/JONES-CarbonFriendlyBeef(27April10).pdf

text:
Unfortunately what you wrote is pure propaganda manipulation. You've been conned. 
Trees grow on land with significant water & low weather extremes. This land is always the most productive. 
Semi-arid/desert land simply cannot support trees, all trees are C3 photosynthesisers & C3 photosynthesis stops when temperatures rise over around 30c & therefore the plant cannot make the energy it needs to survive. 

At 30c, 2 plants that are otherwise the same but one C3 & one C4, the C3 will lose approximately 833 molecules of water per CO2 molecule fixed, while the C4 will lose only 277 molecules of water per CO2 molecule fixed, making C4 plants the ONLY plants that can survive in semi-desert & desert conditions.

C4 plants are grasses. This is why semi-arid areas are always natural grasslands. C4 plants make up 5% of the planet's bio-mass, but are responsible for 23% of it's carbon sequestration. You're barking up the wrong tree if you think trees are the solution to climate change. Grazing ruminants provide C4 grasses with the fertiliser & pruning & seed distribution then need to be healthy (C4 plants require far more sun & fertiliser than C3's). Healthy grasslands sequester 100 tonnes of CO2 per hectare per year. This is well beyond any forest landscape, beaten only by peat swamps

& the highest food per acre is from rice fields simultaneously growing fish for consumption (that's also one of the highest carbon emitting farm system though) Trees are not even in contention as highest yielding crop per acre per year! I don't even know which tree you think would yield even reasonable crop quantities!

& 75 billion tonnes of carbon rich soil is lost each year in the production of just 3.5 billion tonnes of crops. That's 10 tonnes of soil lost every year for every man, woman & child on the planet! That has a HUGE impact on increasing climate change! Properly managed ruminant grazing reverses this & catches that erosion from crop growing & puts that carbon back into the soil to bring atmospheric carbon levels back down

& btw the vast majority of those animals you speak of are 36 day old chickens. Removing the chickens drops the numbers to only 2.6 billion animals killed for direct eating, but hundreds of trillions of mice & other animals killed to produce that 3.5 billion tonnes of crops (averaging 25 mice killed per kilo of crop food produced)

Dave3¬† actaully if the cows are put onto the land of the same quality that is needed to produce that vegan food in that space, then 1 hectare of that land is generally accepted as supporting 8 adult & baby cow pairs (16 cows, equal to 12 adult cows). When intensive managed rotational grazing is used instead of cropping & harvesting, due ot the loss of teh need for drying time of the grain & reduction in grain loss to the ground during harvest, this can easily be increased to 18 growing cows per hectare, using accepted eating quantities & crop production quantities, with cows slaughtered at 12 months of age on average, that totals 30 million calories per hectare. An average person eats a little under 1 million calories per year, so food for 30 people per hectare. Seperate space is not required for animals like chickens though, 3 days after the cows have self-harvested that crop, a trailer full of chickens & their nests can be towed in overnight while they sleep & then opened the next morning to let them eat all the maggots that have grown in the cow manure. This creates an additional 15 million calories per hectare per year in the form of eggs, so that's 45 million calories per hectare per year, or 45 people fed per hectare per year. 
Rice is the highest yielding crop, with 2 crops of 6 tonnes average each, giving 43.8 million calories per year, so that's just under the cow/chicken combo. If fish are added, it can be increased to beat the cow/chicken combo (geese can be added there too btw) & sugarcane can also beat the cow/chicken combo, but no other crops can. Corn could come close IF it wasn't dependent on shortening days to mature, but since it is, it's limited to only 1 crop per year.

You are comparing cows raised on land they are usually raised on, that looks like this https://www.google.com.au/search?q=australian+cattle+station&source=lnms&tbm=isch&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjA3tPOkMfaAhXDGpQKHVZgBRAQ_AUICigB#imgrc=mGGS9nGHV4stmM: with crops grown on prime cropland, that is not a rational comparison. It very much shows that you have never grown any of your own food in your life! You really should start gardening if you want to think you understand how much land is needed to feed a person!

author: HistoryFan476ad

text:
HistoryFan476ad 
:( don‚Äôt say that. If people stop caring, the world is doomed, not just ourselves, but entire ecosystems, and the state of our world for thousands of years as well. You can make a difference, and every person counts. 

I went vegetarian 2 years ago- besides the occasional wild caught salmon.
Its much easier than I thought. I‚Äôve also dropped eggs and milk along the way. It‚Äôs very rewarding, not just for your health but it gives you a sort of peace of mind. 

I know eating meat isn‚Äôt necessarily bad. But the way so much of it is raised is cruel, and something I don‚Äôt think many of us would be capable of if we had to work in those slaughter houses ourselves. Many workers suffer from PTSD afterwards from exposure to all the killing and brutality. 

You can make a difference- and quite big one. I‚Äôm not asking you to go vegan tomorrow, but please do consider that your choices have an affect on our world. Eating just a little less meat helps. Though it seems a small part of the whole, that small part is something that gets us all closer to saving our world.

text:
Nice video and nice that such a huge channel like you talks about what even the big'We save the planet' organisations (like Greenpeace and almost every else) "forget" to talk about (not kidding they say nothing about it at all, one even says, eat meat to save the planet). The numbers I know are a lot more disturbing, the Meat and Dairy/Egg Industrie causes like 51-60% of all ghg, thats also due to that methan is 296x more harmful to our planet than co2, good thing is that the amount of time our planet needs to 'dissolve' the Problem caused by methan is lot less than with CO2. The 25% seemed more like only america. Sadly most animals can't have the'freedom' of the animals that you showed in the video. The animals that are rised like thate are 0,02-0,2% of all the land animals. All other are worse treated than most people in the Kz's in 1940, raped to constantly produces milk, fed with'food' and antibiotics on mass that will let them 'life' for as long as possible, with teeths torn out, beak cut off (the beak of chickens has a similar amount of nerves as the mans genital), castrated, tail cut off etc. and ofc all that without anesthesia. The antibiotics is also in the meat, the result is the illness thats growing more and more frequently also called multi resistant germs. (They are feed every month with Tons of antibiotics so that the industries aren't bothered by them being ill (not few are still ill). Not to forget that thr reason woods are burned and cut down, desertifikation, water Problems and so on are also caused by our agriculture (One hamburger costs like one Dollar, but the planet it costs 660gallions of water and that is just one). Thank you for the video and raising awarness but it had less important information than it could have :p Just seeing the link between the problems isn't possible without the knowledge. To everyone who has read this so long comment, I recommend thr movie 'Cowspiracy'. In 1 and half a hour it will be explained in much more detail than what I wrote, so that you can retrace what I wrote about. 
You all, have a nice day.

text: Brisk of moonligh I‚Äôve looked into it a bit and it‚Äôs likely to do with the amount of protein you are consuming. Protein is a more satiating molecule than carbohydrate and fats and so with a high protein food like meat you will feel fuller. However, you can achieve the same goal with high protein vegan foods, like legumes (peas and beans), nuts and seitan (vital wheat gluten contains between 70 & 80% protein but is deficient in lysine, so make sure you supplement that with legumes)! I was like that at the start, just constantly eating and after making these changes I actually feel fuller for longer. Also don‚Äôt neglect complex carbohydrates either, like wholemeal breads and oats

text: We have so many commenters saying "oh well I'm doing my part, I don't eat that much meat" but what does that really mean? Compared to what? The average American eats animals products in some form or other for every single meal. Bacon and eggs for breakfast, ham sandwich for lunch, baked chicken for dinner. So by that measure, maybe you only eat meat of some kind for like 2/3rds of your meals and you can say "I don't eat that much meat." There is a statistic that something like 90% of Americans claim to eat healthily, but 75% of Americans are overweight or obese.¬†This is why "Reducitarianism" is totally ineffective. People cannot honestly gauge what they are consuming and are doing a lot more damage to themselves and the planet than they even realize. If a person takes the ethical stance against the exploitation of animals and goes vegan, then it's a done deal.  You are not consuming animal products, so you are no longer contributing to the planet-destroying monster that is animal agriculture, which is responsible for 90% of Amazon Rainforest deforestation, 15% of all greenhouse gas emissions, and the total collapse of sea life in the oceans by 2048 from overfishing and the destruction of the coral reef. We have 12 years to make some significant changes to avoid total climate change catastrophe, so "baby-steps" are just not going to cut it.

author: Julia Crowe

text:
For selfish reasons and monetary reasons, please reduce meat consumption drastically as well! This is the biggest and easiest thing we can do for the environment right now. If we don't do anything because of laziness, unwillingness to change, ungrounded fear for nutrient deficiency or, the worst reason of all, 'I just really like the taste', you, and the whole of humanity and all living beings on earth will pay much more for that for that in just a few decades.

This isn't something that governments or corporations will solve, because big corporations are led by old men trying to grab quick, big cash with minimal costs or investment. Governments also follow the money. If we as consumers stop buying stuff, the corporations will listen and change to where the money can be made. This change can only be started from the bottom up and it's already happening. One drop of water against the current can't change the course of the river, but it can cause other drops to change their course, which can in turn get a ripple effect going.

Don't wait, act right now and stop giving the animal industry money. It's as simple as that.

text: ‚Äã¬†@G. Dave3¬† We were herbivore millions of years ago, before our brains grew in size. We started evolving and then went on to eat meat in order to be able to supply our growing brain with enough energy. Then we started cooking our meat, meaning we did not need to evolve in such a way which would make us have the same teeth as flesh eaters. We also have several other factors which show that we are meant to eat meat, for example, the adicity of our stomach. Our stomach acid has a pH of around 1.5, so rather low, meaning that we have a diet high in bacteria. Scavengers have a pH of 1.3, so similar to humans, but herbivores have a pH of around 4.1-6.1 (depending on whether they are a foregut or hindgut herbivore) showing that in fact, our diet naturally contains meat.

text: i'm almost 40. I was raised vegetarian and I've been vegan for the past 5 or so years. I must say I am super reassured by the comments here!  in my relatively short lifetime, so much has changed in terms of awareness around what we eat and how that impacts the health of our bodies and the planet. Seeing the comments, and the open-mindedness of folks here to make small personal changes that will involve short term pain for long term good ---- I think we're in pretty good shape! The comments section can typically be so negative  but here I feel a shared sense of humanity and that we're all in this together.

text:
I gave up eating meat in one day and then a year later stopped eating fish all together. Now I don't eat eggs and I occasionally have cheese. Its all a process. People say they will never go vegan which is what I would have said 3 years ago. But if you make little changes to your diet they add up over time. Just be open to the idea and don't shut off ideas which conflict with what you've been doing or what you've been told your whole life. Going vegan or vegetarian is not a diet, it's a life choice. 

Just start with one meal a week, or one day. Over a lifetime that adds up to be a lot.

text:
This video is more like the second best diet that helps fight climate change... All the facts imply that a vegan diet is more effective at reducing emissions, yet the Mediterranean diet was the focus. That is slightly disingenuous. Meat (Carnism) has such a strong hold on people, the idea of not eating meat was literally out of the question. 

We don‚Äôt all have to go vegan, but if you want to maximize your ethical impact then you should. Veganism doesn‚Äôt just produce way fewer greenhouse gases, it also can leads to more responsible land use and crop production (which was given one sentence in this video), a lower chance of the proliferation of antibiotic resistant bacteria, and avoiding the myriad of others negative environmental impacts of animal agriculture (like damaging water and leading to deforestation). If this was a serious video, it would‚Äôve mentioned veganism more explicitly.
author: The Reasoned Vegan

author: Rebecca Allen

text:
Jeez this video doesn't even get the source of methane from cattle correct. Cattle aren't "gassy". They're foregut fermenters, and the process of methanogenesis in their rumen is what creates CH4 like with any other ruminant including bison, elk, sheep, impala, etc. Methanogens in the rumen produce CH4. So enteric methane is more "burps" than "farts."  That enteric methane also has a context, so like with any source of CH4 emissions you have to look at the entire ecosystem not just GROSS emissions...You have to look at NET emissions instead.  Net emissions account for CH4 sinks as well. These sinks include geospehric sinks like methanotrophic bacteria in the soil, and tropospheric sinks likehydroxyl radicals in the atmosphere. In fact, most CH4 is oxidized, and CH4 in general is short lived so it doesn't accumulate as much as CO2, this is why the whole notion of CO2 equivalency is being re-evaluated - Read:  https://www.oxfordmartin.ox.ac.uk/news/2018_news_Climate_Pollutants_GWP

I go into this all in a lot more detail here in this blog entry: 
Ruminations: Methane math and context https://lachefnet.wordpress.com/2018/05/04/ruminations-methane-math-and-context

###

text:
what a load of crap on so many levels.  I wonder what large Grain based Food company paid for this research?   But Frank Mitloehner, an air quality specialist from the University of California at Davis (UCD), said the U.N. reached its conclusions for the livestock sector by adding up emissions from farm to table, including the gases produced by growing animal feed; animals' digestive emissions; and processing meat and milk into foods.

But its figures for transport did not add up emissions from well to wheel; instead, it considered only emissions from fossil fuels burned while driving.

"This lopsided 'analysis' is a classical apples-and-oranges analogy that truly confused the issue," Mitloehner said on the university's Web site.

Mitloehner also pointed to the fact that leading authorities agree raising animals for food accounts for about 3 percent of all greenhouse gas emissions in the U.S., while transportation creates an estimated 26 percent.http://www.cnn.com/2010/TECH/science/03/24/meat.industry.global.warming/index.html

text:
The project "Global Warming Petition" shows the state of science based on effective scientific facts.

31,487 American scientists say that global warming is not human-caused and there is no cause for any alarm over our CO2 emissions. They signed a petition with the following purpose:

The purpose of the Petition Project is to demonstrate that the claim of ‚Äúsettled science‚Äù and an overwhelming ‚Äúconsensus‚Äù in favor of the hypothesis of human-caused global warming and consequent climatological damage is wrong. No such consensus or settled science exists. As indicated by the petition text and signatory list, a very large number of American scientists reject this hypothesis.

Publicists at the United Nations, Mr. Al Gore, and their supporters frequently claim that only a few ‚Äúskeptics‚Äù remain ‚Äì skeptics who are still unconvinced about the existence of a catastrophic human-caused global warming emergency.

It is evident that 31,487 Americans with university degrees in science ‚Äì including 9,029 PhDs, are not "a few." Moreover, from the clear and strong petition statement that they have signed, it is evident that these 31,487 American scientists are not ‚Äúskeptics.‚Äù

These scientists are instead convinced that the human-caused global warming hypothesis is without scientific validity and that government action on the basis of this hypothesis would unnecessarily and counterproductively damage both human prosperity and the natural environment of the Earth.

Nobody can ignore the fact that 31,487 American scientists have signed this petition, including 9,029 with PhDs ‚Äì http://www.petitionproject.org

text:
Even though it doesn't seem like there is that big of a difference between vegan, vegetarian, and Mediterranean diets, the impact you make on the animals is large. Vegan is the least harmful to living beings. Dairy, eggs, and fish still have a large amount of cruelty behind them. So when choosing a diet that cause the least amount of harm to the environment AND to the animals, vegan is the way to go. 

Check out Earthlings on Netflix to see the cruelty that actually that is necessary in the dairy, egg, and fishing industry. By cutting out these products as well as other meats from our diets, you are doing the least harm imaginable. Which should always be the goal.

text: Love this video! I especially like the argument that you don't have to be full-on vegan to have a significant impact on your health, the planet and our resources. I find this is sometimes a "turn off" for those folks who want to do something but don't want to give up meat entirely. I get it and I think it's important for them to know that even cutting their current meat consumption by 1/2 can have a HUGE positive impact! I follow a 90% plant-based diet and am happy to say that after leading by example (and cooking for my friends and showing them how amazing plant-based/vegan meals can be), I have influenced at least two people to go plant-based and a handful of others to consider reducing red meat consumption and opting for fish instead. Thanks again!!

text:
One thing thats not really brought up in this video at all is vegetables and fruit are literally flown in from halfway around the world as a lot are not native or in season. A vast majority of what you'd buy from the supermarket to fulfil a human body on a plant based diet has been:
1. Grown (With bone meal and animal blood for minerals)
2. Harvested (Polluting machinery)
3. Packaged (Harmful to environment)
4. Transported (Literally flown halfway across the world)
Therefore the information in this video is irrelevant and misleading. If we all started a ketogenic diet incorporating locally raised/grass fed animals and local in season vegetables, not only would we need to eat less (High fat consumption means eating less meals) but we would reduce our carbon footprint enormously.

text: How about the USA signing the Paris Climate accord, how about the Conservative party admitting global warming. If companies can go more eco, normal people would not have to cut their meat consumption too hard to save the planet. By the way, Asians consume less meat than Europeans and Americans, but Asians rarely claim to be vegan. In the west, being vegan is almost a political gesture, but In Asian, it's just a personal thing, a personal choice. My grandma, may her soul rest in peace, used to go vegetarian only during the weekend, for her own well-being and for paying respect to Buddha. She was eating at the same table with us, eating only veggie dishes while the rest of us were eating both meat and vegetables, and no question asked, knowing that Chinese share dishes at the table, instead of serving them separately for each one like in Western fashioned table service, and that does not disturb anyone. So it's not about going vegan or not, it's about everyone thinks they've got the right to pick other's nose just because people do things differently and have different thoughts. They used to fight for religions, and still are, and now they fight for food choice. That is the so-called supremacy of the Western culture, seems like stupidity and arrogance, just like Cain in the Bible.

text: There's other little things you can do to still eat a lot of meat, without the carbon footprints. author: Tim Kohut

text: As others have said being vegan prevents many forms of harm. Obviously there's the environmental impact as stated (and yes, I agree reducing is worthwhile), the benefit to the animals that aren't being slaughter or treated as commodities which causes inherent harm in a capitalist society. It's also important to note the impact on humans and I don't mean the health of those eating meat or even those in developing countries who are most effected by climate change. Slaughter house workers (how are largely immigrants and poor people) have extremely high rates of mental health issues given the unnatural and damaging nature of their work- repeatedly slaughtering sentient animals over and over again. Communities where a new slaughter house is built see crime rates sky rocket- likely due to either mental health issues or harmful adaptation (i.e. shutting down your sensitivity or compassion in order to carry out your job). We should shut down all slaughter houses and if you want to eat meat you can kill the animal yourself. Obviously, I also think we should be limited to 1 meat meal a week at most. Ideally none but I could live with once a month or once a year.
author: Reef Larkin

text: THIS, so much of the plastic in the Oceans comes from fishing. I get that videos like this want to appeal to a broad base but it feels a little patronizing to not give a full and clear picture. Also, for the purpose of climate equality I'm a big believer that those of us in western, economically stable parts of the world (especially those of us who have money and live in cities with a lot of choice) have a duty to do the hardest work and simply reducing your meat intake doesn't seem hard enough when developing nations are simply going through the economic booms we've been through already. I hear so often that there's some locally farmed alternative, or it's okay if we go fishing once a week but honestly, is that reasonable and more importantly, do many people actually live like this? I live on an island where I'm never more than 72 miles away from the sea and yet I've only known one person in my life who actually fishes their own food and the last time I saw him, he'd gone vegan.
author: Edie Lee

text: The vast majority of meat and dairy consumed is from factory farming so comparing what sounds like a 'wellness' vegan diet consisting of mainly 'superfoods' to a diet of locally sourced, minimal animal products is not very helpful because neither account for anywhere near the majority of diets followed globally or even just in western countries. Even if my beans come in a plastic bag, I'm pretty sure their equivalent would be a plastic-packaged piece of meat which would absolutely have a higher carbon footprint per gram of protein provided. My view on this is that, yes, we need to change the way we think of food packaging and move toward a reusable system but that has very little to do with what diet you're following for the vast majority of people. From vegetables to chicken nuggets, most of our food comes in unnecessary packaging that will outlive us all. Just because a vegan diet isn't perfect, does not mean it should be discounted as the worst thing that can happen is you save a lot of lives, and the best is that you also make a huge dent in the climate crisis.
author: Edie Lee
