text:
¬†@sprout s¬†  These results are from two different studies. I've cited the links below. The first one gives the numbers with respect to a questionnaire of food choices while the second one actually recorded the daily habits of the subjects for a period of 7 days. 

 "The age-and-sex-adjusted mean (95 % confidence interval) GHG emissions in kilograms of carbon dioxide equivalents per day (kgCO2e/day) were 7.19 (7.16, 7.22) for high meat-eaters (‚Äâ>‚Äâ=‚Äâ100 g/d), 5.63 (5.61, 5.65) for medium meat-eaters (50-99 g/d), 4.67 (4.65, 4.70) for low meat-eaters (‚Äâ<‚Äâ50 g/d), 3.91 (3.88, 3.94) for fish-eaters, 3.81 (3.79, 3.83) for vegetarians and 2.89 (2.83, 2.94) for vegans." https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4372775/

"The omnivorous choice generated worse carbon, water and ecological footprints than other diets. No differences were found for the environmental impacts of ovo-lacto-vegetarians and vegans, which also had diets more adherent to the Mediterranean pattern. A high inter-individual variability was observed through principal component analysis, showing that some vegetarians and vegans have higher environmental impacts than those of some omnivores.  Thus, regardless of the environmental benefits of plant-based diets, there is a need for thinking in terms of individual dietary habits." https://www.nature.com/articles/s41598-017-06466-8

I used to eat a lot more meat. I actually developed copper toxicity from my copper IUD birth control device, it gave me super long heavy periods.... So I really detest any shaming of anyone for personal dietary choices bc you and even they might not know all that is driving them and the body has an intelligence of its own if we listen and try to give in to the healthier cravings, it does indicate what it wants or needs it‚Äôs a matter of interpreting it well.... but since I‚Äôve sorted that out and I cleansed from heavy metal and I pumped lots of good minerals to make up for being depleted for so long- now it is much easier for me to eat even less meat. I do tend to stick to a Mediterranean diet, heavy on protein but not all animal sources, I go for fish and chicken (I also like to eat LOW on the seafood food chain, bc predatory fish at the top are both A. Overfished and B. Loaded with heavy metals, and I‚Äôd rather have oysters or lobster over tuna or swordfish any day) , rice & beans, veggies & greens, and only crave red meat about once a month anyway. I do still consume dairy like eggs, butter & milk. But I try to stick to organic and local as well. I really enjoy and love food and eat a lot, I graze all day, I consider it a worthwhile investment in my own long term health. I don‚Äôt feel guilty about an $8 green juice from Whole Foods that has fresh dandelion greens & burdock root to help cleanse my liver so it can do its job cleansing toxins from my body and keeping me healthier :P 
One of the coolest meat operations I‚Äôve come across is Wild Idea Buffalo Co out of South Dakota what they do is amazing check it out- also the most lean, tender amazing steak you‚Äôll ever eat in your life!

text: It is clear that the way we produce food is having a huge impact on our environment and climate change, but I think this video misses a couple of important points.  When we grow crops we till the earth and that releases massive amounts of CO2 into the atmosphere so a vegan diet can have great effects on the environment.  On the other hand a pasture where that grass feed cow is being grazed can sequester carbon and use methane for plant growth even if those animals produce those elements at the same the same time.  Please don't simplify this equation too much!   Nature has been managing itself for billions of years before we came along so don't think we can solve things by getting rid of meat, livestock just might be an essential part of the equation that fixes climate change.

text: It‚Äôs true that livestock emit methane and nearly all aspects of agriculture have a carbon footprint; however, U.S. animal agriculture is much more efficient than in other parts of the world. In the U.S., livestock are responsible for 3.8 percent of GHG emissions while transportation accounts for 26.4 percent, according to U.S. Environmental Protection Agency data. In California, 5.4 percent of GHG emissions are attributed to livestock and 37 percent to transportation, according to the California Air Resources Board.While it is vital that scientists in UC ANR, and elsewhere, assist ranchers to continue diminishing the carbon hoofprint, it is also important to recognize that meat can serve as a high-quality protein source as part of a nutritious diet. The VOX video does note that not all livestock is raised equally, and that rangeland can be used to sequester carbon, but it neglects to mention that grazing cows also provide numerous ecosystem services, such as eating plants that could fuel wildfires.It should also be noted how livestock fit into the larger food system picture. Almost 60 percent of the world's agricultural land is grazing land and is unsuitable for producing crops. Ruminants serve a valuable role in the food system by converting the forages humans cannot consume into a nutrient-dense food.UC ANR advisors and specialists continuously strive to improve livestock production practices; however, that is only one of many approaches we need to pursue to solve the challenges of climate change. Time, research and money should be invested where they will produce the most benefit for society. Encouraging people to focus on livestock, rather than on much larger sources of GHG emissions, can lead to policies that slow our efforts to develop more effective climate change solutions."

I‚Äôm going to try to not come off as a crazy vegan who‚Äôs trying to make everyone vegan (I feel like people are entitled to their own decision despite what I morally feel) but all of what I‚Äôm about to say is backed by science. There is so much Co2 in the atmosphere that we can no long plant enough trees to save us. Animal farming is responsible for 60% of gas emissions for animal agriculture which is killing the planet. Besides that, our bodies are not made to consume meat: Heart disease, diabetes (yes diabetes can be from consumption of meat), cancer and other harmful diseases and fatal conditions can be reduced and come to an end if the consumption of meat is either reduced or illuminated. Another example is the evolution of human teeth. Our canines are very small and we no longer need or molars/wisdom‚Äôs due to us not consuming meat the way early humans did. Overall, humans have been consuming animal product for an extremely long time and there‚Äôs no excuse for people who say that there are no options in the vegan lifestyle. From this, humans could not simply just stop all together due to that not being realistic; we would have to  gradually reduce the intake of meat/ animal products but for the people that would be more into just trying it out for a day, go for it. There‚Äôs even a thing called the Seven Day Vegan Challenge which is great because you can see what works for you and you don‚Äôt have to commit to it unles you feel like this lifestyle is for you.(if you do try this please don‚Äôt snackand just not eat. Once again there are PLENTY of options out there. By the end of the week you will feel a lot better) Simply just eating cleaner and healthier would do so much for our planet and our race, the HUMAN RACE.

text:
Jeez this video doesn't even get the source of methane from cattle correct. Cattle aren't "gassy". They're foregut fermenters, and the process of methanogenesis in their rumen is what creates CH4 like with any other ruminant including bison, elk, sheep, impala, etc. Methanogens in the rumen produce CH4. So enteric methane is more "burps" than "farts."  That enteric methane also has a context, so like with any source of CH4 emissions you have to look at the entire ecosystem not just GROSS emissions...You have to look at NET emissions instead.  Net emissions account for CH4 sinks as well. These sinks include geospehric sinks like methanotrophic bacteria in the soil, and tropospheric sinks likehydroxyl radicals in the atmosphere. In fact, most CH4 is oxidized, and CH4 in general is short lived so it doesn't accumulate as much as CO2, this is why the whole notion of CO2 equivalency is being re-evaluated - Read:  https://www.oxfordmartin.ox.ac.uk/news/2018_news_Climate_Pollutants_GWP

I go into this all in a lot more detail here in this blog entry: 
Ruminations: Methane math and context https://lachefnet.wordpress.com/2018/05/04/ruminations-methane-math-and-context

###

text: Humans are creatures of habit. It is a waste of time and effort to try to convince people to change their habits because of your supposed "facts" surrounding an issue. There are over 7 billion of us on earth today, but there were less than 1 billion people 100 years ago. We did not, and could not sustain this intense population growth and development by eating vegetables alone. Meat, makes people "feel full" quicker, and stay feeling satisfied much longer than a meal of vegetables. People act and form habits on feelings and emotions, not from cold hard facts. I am all for responsible choices and reversing our contribution to climate change, but anyone who thinks the answer to this problem is simply telling people to eat less meat, is blinded by naivety.

text: People are animals. Our personal decisions are not driven primarily by ethics, but by appetites and urges, especially when it comes to food. The only way to make a meaningful dent in the contributions of animal agriculture to greenhouse gas emissions is to change public policies that make meat relatively more expensive and less profitable relative to vegetable agriculture. Unless the governments of the world start taking sustainability seriously, make no mistake, our species will wipe itself out. It is hopelessly naive to trust that appeals to some kind of innate human goodness are sufficient to curtail the destructive effects of the human swarm's natural appetite for meat, or our other selfish impulses for that matter. People will alter their habits when they are forced to do so, and not a moment sooner.
author: Horizonberg

text: This is a very important discussion to have, and the video makes some great recommendations‚Äîit seems odd that people adopt an all-or-nothing attitude when it comes to meat consumption, especially since from a health perspective mostly veggies and occasional meat works very well. I also have heard, however, that the evidence that everyone switching to a no-meat diet would be best for the environment is not exactly foolproof. Animals graze and make use of land which we could never use directly for food (e.g., cows in certain pastures eat grass that I could never eat), and so their presence in the food ecosystem can help eliminate inefficiencies. Some folks accordingly argue that the ecological ideal wouldn't involve removing animals completely from the food ecosystem. I would be interested in hearing more about that part of the discussion, too.

text:
Very nice video ! There's a coulpe of things I didn't like, and I'd like to clarify for those people who really want to be careful about their impact : first of all, "mediterranean diet" doesn't mean much, it doesn't have a strict definition ( trust me, I'm Italian, and I know we can do much better than today), so telling people "start eating mediterranean" might be misleading, it's not much different from saying "reduce your beef consumption", even though it sounds cool. 

More importantly,  the video gives us the feeling that a certain food is always better than another ( fish better than meat, veggies better than fish).  However one must know that there's a huge difference between some different kind of fish, ( salmon, which is shown in the video, is actually one of the most CO2-intense, you'd better go for some small fish like makerel or harrings if you want to help the planet).
And remember that the kind of food you eat is not the only thing that matters,  you have to consider where it comes from and how it was produced. For example, a mango is a fruit, but if it has to be shipped by plane to come to your table, it might be enviromentally worse than meat.

Here's my video about the topic, you can also find nice references to scientific literature in the video description.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x9xGPP2utr4

text: Not really, because solar power is not environmentally friendly. It takes a lot of mining and a lot of CO2 to produce those solar panels. Batteries are also terrible for the environment, and all of these "renewable" energy sources require solar panels to store the energy. Plus, none of that stuff works in places like Canada, where it gets so cold in the winter that batteries freeze and lose efficiency, and there's very little sun. There's a funny picture of a wind turbine frozen solid, and a helicopter is being used to unfreeze it, burning all kinds of fossil fuels just to unfreeze this wind turbine. Even if we switch to 100% renewable energy, we will always need fossil fuels as an emergency backup. Germany went renewable, and it actually increased their use of coal, because they needed more and more "backup" systems. Just use fossil fuels like a normal person.

text: I feel like what people don't really understand about climate change is that the problem isn't really what we're doing to the Earth, because it'll recover just fine after we're gone. And this idea that we should just all lay down and die in order to save the planet is really toxic and unhelpful. We need to have compassion for each other and for ourselves.
author: AlwaysGonnaSing

text: Moreover, it's not actually average working class people that are the ones most responsible for the environmental destruction. It's the greedy rich CEOs of companies that dump their waste in poor communities because they know that they'll be able to protect themselves from any of the negative effects. They can afford to not care about the consequences of their actions, which is scary since they hold so much power and social capital. Those are the main ones we need to focus on fighting and holding accountable.
author: AlwaysGonnaSing

text: I think personal responsibility and lifestyle change is important, but more for the reason of demonstrating that we are capable of thriving without being dependent on the system we currently live in. You know, showing that there is a better potential future for us that we can all work toward.

text:
Jeez this video doesn't even get the source of methane from cattle correct. Cattle aren't "gassy". They're foregut fermenters, and the process of methanogenesis in their rumen is what creates CH4 like with any other ruminant including bison, elk, sheep, impala, etc. Methanogens in the rumen produce CH4. So enteric methane is more "burps" than "farts."  That enteric methane also has a context, so like with any source of CH4 emissions you have to look at the entire ecosystem not just GROSS emissions...You have to look at NET emissions instead.  Net emissions account for CH4 sinks as well. These sinks include geospehric sinks like methanotrophic bacteria in the soil, and tropospheric sinks likehydroxyl radicals in the atmosphere. In fact, most CH4 is oxidized, and CH4 in general is short lived so it doesn't accumulate as much as CO2, this is why the whole notion of CO2 equivalency is being re-evaluated - Read: https://www.oxfordmartin.ox.ac.uk/news/2018_news_Climate_Pollutants_GWP
I go into this all in a lot more detail here in this blog entry: 
Ruminations: Methane math and context https://lachefnet.wordpress.com/2018/05/04/ruminations-methane-math-and-context

text: Alina Rapaj ...Do you want to see animal cruelty reduced and the environment spared? Or do you want to be the most right person in the Youtube comment section? Ideally yes, everyone in the world should be vegan if their health and income allows it, for both ethical and environmental reasons. However, the jump from vegetarian to vegan, nevermind from a standard American diet, is a drastic life change for most. It's re-learning a basic daily function and it won't happen overnight. People who are considering this change are put off by militant vegans on the internet with their all-or-nothing stances on diet and ethics. It makes the changes seem insurmountable. Whereas promoting at least a reduction in meat and animal product intake will help the environment immensely and reduce animal suffering. Be reasonable, logical, sympathetic, and solution oriented. In the future we will likely all be vegan, but change does not happen overnight.

It is an imperative of capitalism's ideology to maximize profit and cultivate anything that will lead to it, it seems, and often ruthlessly. The truth is displacing culpability to small scale individual choices in consuming is unlikely to  actually effect systemic production(?) How many billions of individuals are there in the consuming developed world? ( The problem isn't the cooking of meat, but the processes that go into its growth - i.e. it will already be there before it is purchased).  In part (perhaps in a Zizek-ian style point, forgive me) this displaces the actual site for large scale change into guilt on the individual's part - and modest alterations that unless, a larger crisis brings to bear on the larger terms, postpones actually any systemic change ? text:
Alexandra Utke it‚Äôs the Monterey Bay Aquarium Seafood Watch Guide / app. They make a list of Best / Good / Bad seafood to favor or avoid.... Whole Foods in some places I heard partnered with them and tries to adhere to its guidelines but I don‚Äôt know how diligent they are about it- as consumers if we all put pressure on them and make calls or write in suggestions or feedback or complaints- they should get the message and respond. But individually that is a great mention- the Seafood Watch is a helpful tool to let you know what‚Äôs better or worse. There‚Äôs issues with farming but.... it can also be done better or worse so I guess I support best practices in farmed fisheries.... personally I generally stick to Salmon either wild or farmed.... I tend to stay away from Tuna or Swordfish, or any other large predatory fishes or endangered animals- especially sharks!!! I favor Salmon, Oysters, and love Lobster and crab too. I‚Äôm really content to just stick with that and never really crave anything else. Although Uni fresh sea urchin is amazing, like an Ocean mousse, and eel is also really yummy, so I just tend to love the little guys on the foodchain :) and they tend to be more plentiful.... but a problem is bottom Trawling, and by-catch - so the method of fishing is important. Crabs here in California tend to be caught by smallish traps- near the cost where big boats can‚Äôt go. It‚Äôs very regulated. So I feel good about eating crab. Oysters are generally ‚Äúfarmed‚Äù or cultivated and tended to in their own natural cove environments.... I‚Äôm sure it has some impact but I‚Äôm not concerned about it being really harmful. Least of my worries. In fact, Hog Island Oyster Co was recently mentioned on NPR for being a canary in the coal mine- sounding the alarm that yes the oceans are becoming too acidic due to sinking carbon from the atmosphere for us- but shelled organisms are pretty much doomed .... the ocean will be too acidic for them to grow their shells- and they‚Äôll just die off and we will have no more Oysters- no more shellfish- which is also going to be a problem for the rest of the whole ocean ecosystem- no more plankton with their tiny exoskeletons.... that‚Äôs Whale Food.... that means the Whales will die. Hot Island Oyster Co is working on ways to save their own business of course - they have found that sea plants take carbon out of the ocean just like land plants take it out of the air. So they are planting more sea kelp and sea grass for their oysters, and THOSE oysters get to enjoy a little micro-biome or microclimate that is less acidic and allows them to live. So.... I will definitely still be eating my oysters and have to pay Hog Island a visit :) 

Who really wants to live in a world without Whales???? :( 

It is definitely worth eating responsibly for. 

Our choices even the little ones DO matter and add up. 

Rice & Beans, farm fresh eggs.... some seafood.... Mediterranean is a great way to go.

text: Steffen Ernst I worked in a fish hatchery growing catfish and tapia and in comparison to cows, chicken, and pig. Farm raised fish are probably you best option for substantial food source. The biggest issue is water. But the feed can be plant base or if the fish out omnivorous they can eat algae/aquatic weeds that occur naturally plus fish feed. The fish themselves aren‚Äôt injected with hormones like chicken has been found to be. And as long as they are care for properly the risk of the fish having diseases are slim. Most seafood related illnesses are bc of undercook meat or in the case of oyster there caught out of season or just not frozen fast enough to kill the vibrio. My recommendation is that if you are buying fish check if it was farmed raised or not, if yes see where the farm is located. In my experience most Americans fish farms are under strict guidelines from how the fish is raised to how they harvest, packaged, and shipped out. So really just be aware my dude where your buying from.

text:
Robert Spence, you used a personal experience or an isolated example instead of a sound argument or compelling evidence. It's often much easier for people to believe someone's testimony as opposed to understanding complex data and variation across a continuum. Quantitative scientific measures are almost always more accurate than personal perceptions and experiences, but our inclination is to believe that which is tangible to us, and/or the word of someone we trust over a more 'abstract' statistical reality.

Example: Jason said that that was all cool and everything, but his grandfather smoked, like, 30 cigarettes a day and lived until 97 - so don't believe everything you read about meta analyses of methodologically sound studies showing proven causal relationships.

Americans eat the most meat, are the most obese, and mostly die from heart and weight related diseases.
author: Bex Ed

text: Bex Ed Of course I did. Your lecture is cute because research is my occupation. I knew what I was doing in response to the OP. My N=1 argument is every bit as valid as the OPs blanket statement. Correlation does not equal causation.
author: Robert Spence

text: Is your very well thought out argument "I am healthy even though I eat meat", so the guy calling the US "land of the heart attacks, strokes, and fatties" is completely wrong? Correlation does indeed not equal causation but Americans are really fat.
author: Bex Ed

text: Bex Ed Yes, Americans are obese and unhealthy as a population, but the issues are complex. Americans also eat a diet very high in inexpensive, calorie dense and nutrient poor snack and junk foods. Go to a grocery store and you typically see grocery carts with more fried chips, cookies, cheap frozen meals, rather than fresh vegetables, dairy, and quality cuts of meat and fish. Much of the meat eaten is via fast food, which is also laden with low quality fats, sodium, and low quality meats, as well as lacking in soluble and insoluble fibers. The issue is FAR more complex than stating "Americans eat more meat per capita and are obese, therefore meat is bad". That is a non-valid argument and is merely correlation.
author: Robert Spence

text: Bex Ed BTW, I performed a personal experiment with a ketogenic diet, which is largely meat, fat, and low carb veggie based diet. I conducted blood labs before, during, and after my experience. All health markers improved, including a fantastic reduction in total cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL. HDL went up. Interesting. The likely reason is that I was in caloric deficit and cut bodyfat during this period. Although I shifted from a grains and higher carbohydrate fruit/veggie diet to a diet much higher in fat (including saturated fats), my lipid profile improved significantly. My experience is N=1, however it is a valid anecdote. BTW, there is fantastic emerging research in the role our digestive microbiome has with overall health, as well as more current research in the effect of mono, poly, unsaturated as well as saturated fats on health, and the modern research continues to swim against the tide of the older body of literature.
author: Robert Spence

text: Robert Spence, well I agree with your comment completely, of course it is a complex issue. And I know food culture in the US has become pretty bad (I am Finnish myself and we also have junk and substitutes and frozen over fresh, but not to the same extent + our school food tends to be great). Of course there are many problems to tackle. But I would not argue against the general idea of "both the health of Americans and the environment would benefit from Americans eating less meat".
author: Bex Ed

text: Bex Ed I would not argue with that. I would add " reduce calorie intake, become more active, eat more fiberous foods (from grains and fruit/vegetables), and limit consumption of corn based products for environmental reasons, including corn fed animal products. I only eat grass fed beef, free range chicken/eggs, and wild caught fish (for health reasons as well as environmental reasons).

text:
Well, I'm not lying. It actually happened. But it isn't mutually exclusive. Yeah, going vegan I had to give up cheetos. But I can still have coke and oreos. So I generally have more plant based diet, and I have less options for junk food, so I eat less of it. But I still have plenty of junk food.
As for meat replacements, tofu, tempeh, seitan, mushroom, lentils, they are always lower in calories, fat, and cholesterol than meat, especially processed meat. 
Simply put, I just eat less calories now because my substitutions are less calorically dense. But I still eat crap now and then; I'm still a human with cravings. It's pretty great.
author: freshbingo

text:
yeh so in other words it has NOTHING to do with not eating meat! You could have switched to lean, grass fed meat or game meat & the SAME junk food changes you made & the result would have been identical in terms of your weight/health.

I just maintain that until I get my weight back where I want to & then slowly reintroduce grains to replace meat until I hit a balance where my weight has stopped falling. tbh, the ONLY time I put on weight is if I'm short on money & reduce the meat in my diet as a result. 

& my cholesterol is low & my BP is on the low side but acceptable

text:
There are alot of vegans and vegetarians, but there are just too many ignorant, impudent, naive, and just down right inhumane people who take this ever so lightly or not at all. Not to mention the idiototic children you see on the comments of butchering videos that say "Mm they're crying and suffering make my hamburgers even better". As funny as they believe themselves to be, they'll never change. Even people who don't think twice about climate change or the suffering animals and live in their own little world. Where if nothing harms them now, how could they change their lives for the benefit of others? Humans are selfish creatures. I mean its not even about telling people anymore. Its just talking to a brick wall, but even a brick wall has a bigger IQ than that kid behind the screen poking fun at the suffering of other creatures. I do like to think positively about wanting to be vegan. I mean recently 400,000+ less animals were killed the past decade due to veganism. It just digusts me that people are so naive. So simple minded and one sided that they cant even change something that will never even benefit them. Addiction is that cause. Just look at white people. With their hunting and meaningless slaughter of animals. While deer isn't a big part of climate change, I'm talking about the people who do hunt. Its because they hunt that they don't care about any other animals besides their dog. They'll devour any cooked carcass in sight. Unaware of the tons of negatives there are to even consume meat. Meat, dairy products, GMOs, and artificial preservatives are all sources of cancer, obesity, and addiction. Of course there aren't enough people who even know that because the industries are purposely wanting you to get cancer one day. Population control. Also they want money of course. They couldnt care less about you. If that wasn't true then why do the biggest industries of meat consumption pretty shove their advertising down everyones throat? Do you see vegetable and vegan meals advertised? Of course not. Anyways, in my opinion, this world is done for as it is. I mean, look who's president for god's sake. No one will change and no one will care, but every person who does is obviously helping tremendously already. They're not selfish unlike a majority of our species. If you're offended by this, take it up with someone who cares. If not, spread the word. Help the world. Help all sentient beings that we share this earth with. If not for them, for the people you love then. Climate change affects everyone. This is as real as the phone or computer in your face. So you decide. Decide fast because time waits for no man. I repeat...
Time waits for no man.

text:
hmm so if you take a fat (BMI over 30), uneducated smoking person who doesn't exercise & feed them fried chicken everyday for 5 years, at the end of that time they'll be even fatter - who would have thought lol  (amazing it's only 2kgs they gain in 5 years, but then I guess when the majority of your numbers rely on self reporting that could explain it.... ) http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/92/2/398/T2.expansion.html
"Weight gain was only weakly related to the intake of red meat [M3: Œ≤ (95% CI) = 15 (1, 28), P = 0.03]. The association with processed meat was similar to that observed for total meat [M3: Œ≤ (95% CI) = 25 (15, 34), P < 0.0001]. The strongest association was shown for poultry [M3: Œ≤ (95% CI) = 45 (29, 62), P < 0.0001]."

oh & there was another group that put on more weight with meat too 
"In addition, the relation between red meat and weight gain was also stronger in physically active subjects compared with moderately inactive or inactive subjects" who would have thunk! People who go to the gym & work out lots add more muscle when they eat more meat lol

This is interesting too "Meat intake was not significantly associated with weight gain in all centers with a negative average of the prudent pattern score (except Denmark and Norway)"

"The strongest relation with annual weight change was observed for poultry. However, when subjects with previous illness and those likely to misreport their energy intake at baseline were excluded from the analyses, the association of weight gain with poultry was attenuated and the strongest association was observed for processed meat. This suggests that this result may be driven mainly by subjects with previous illness or weight-loss attempts that lead to diet intervention, as well as those who misreported their dietary intakes.

Our results appear to contradict experimental studies that provide evidence of short-term increases in satiety and thermogenesis and decreased energy intake with high-protein diets (54). It has also been shown that obese subjects on a low-carbohydrate/high-protein diet lost more weight after 3 mo than did those on a conventional diet (11). However, results were not confirmed after 1 y of follow-up (11, 55). Furthermore, most of the intervention studies specifically on meat intake (21‚Äì26) did not find any weight change difference when energy from carbohydrates was partially substituted with meat (23‚Äì26). These differences could be linked to differences in the food substitutions performed as well as differences in the population's initial dietary habits. With control of energy intake for 9 wk, postmenopausal women who ate a diet supplemented with chicken (n = 15) lost significantly more body mass than did those supplemented with shortbread cookies and sugar-coated chocolates rich in carbohydrate and fat (n = 14) (21). All the other studies that substituted meat with healthier food such as soy products and legumes (23, 26), bread, pasta and rice (24), or fish, eggs, and cheese (25) did not find any significant weight-loss difference between the 2 interventions. In our study, the association between meat consumption and weight gain was weaker in subjects with a low prudent pattern score. Furthermore, meat intake was not significantly associated with weight gain in all centers with a negative average of the prudent pattern score (except Denmark and Norway), which indicates that the association could be diluted in populations with high consumptions of other high-energy-dense foods."


So it appears that that study (with it's self reporting) confirms that eating lean unprocessed red meat as part of a healthy lifestyle, including reasonable exercise doesn't impact on weight in the majority of people, meanwhile those who switch from red meat to chicken are more likely to increase their weight, but all weight gains in the study were too low to be significant anyway. At least it's a reputably reported study - if you go to the actual study, that video is clearly a bunch of crap - given it doesn't even link to the study!

text: Vlad G With all due respect your argument is almost entirely invalid. Your assumption is that if people went vegan they would solely rely on soy as a substitute for meat but this is far from the truth. In fact almost half of vegans (41%) don‚Äôt consume soy as we are cations of the way it impacts the environment. You are also disregarding the fact that livestock requires much more food and water than soybeans and it just ends up being wasted as the animals that have consumed so much of the resources that could feed humans are slaughtered. To argue that more land use = more harmful for environment is utterly foolish, you have to account for resources. Also if your disregarding co2 and it‚Äôs impact on the climate than you have lost all credibility in your argument. If your going to disregard scientific evidence then you pretty much have the same argument as people who argue for flat earth in which case debating is pointless because you don‚Äôt back your claims with fact. If your misinterpretation of veganism and continued consumption of products that are harmful for the planet helps you sleep at night, so be it.
author: Chris Andersen

text: The argument for soy applies to all plant farming. It takes up more land and contributes to more deforestation and soil erosion than any animal farm. If everyone went vegan, we'd have LESS land because we'd have to cut down more and more rainforests in order to use MORE and MORE land to grow more and more plants. Agriculture destroys the environment more than ranching. The most environmentally friendly way to eat - hunting wild animals, or foraging for wild plants/mushrooms. That way you don't use a bunch of land to grow monocultures. what you're suggesting is that we cover more and more land with industrial agriculture planting unsustainable fields of monocultures that destroy the ecosystem.
author: Vlad G

text: Vlad G I‚Äôm not suggesting that at all. I totally understand your perspective and how cutting down trees for new land isn‚Äôt sustainable. I am however suggesting that instead of following the typical industrial holocaust that is the meat and dairy industry (where we feed and kill animals at an exponential rate) we use the resources towards the ever growing human population. It takes much more resources to feed and maintain a cow than a human so in that sense it would be way more efficient to just give people the resources directly as opposed to doing it through animals just for more profit. We don‚Äôt have to destroy any new land at all, just use what we currently have more efficiently. If we‚Äôre using our agriculture towards animals and not humans just so we can eat the animals then this is the least sustainable way for food production. Is it understandable now? I don‚Äôt understand why you can‚Äôt see the logic.
author: Chris Andersen

text: Vlad G ‚ÄúAbout 85 percent of the world‚Äôs soybean crop is processed into meal and vegetable oil, and virtually all of that meal is used in animal feed. text: Gotta disagree with you there chikita - humans have evolved to be omnivorous.  In fact if you look at early human evolution eating meat is arguably one of the factors that led to the development of modern human traits - like larger brain size, tool use, skeletal structure, cooperation, etc. etc. Also not all human populations suffer medical problems from diets high in meat and animal protein.  Inuit tribes eat much more meat than the average American but don't suffer the same health consequences.  I think you make a lot of valid points, but most of the problems with an omnivorous diet and benefits of a vegan diet have arisen in the last hundred years or so, after the agricultural industry really industrialized and changed our food sheds so radically, and within an evolutionarily short period of time.
author: Briana

text:
¬†@The Captain¬† Sure, our monkey ancestors were herbivores, but we would have never evolved to where we are if we never ate meat. Many studies have also pointed out that our bodies indicate that we are designed to eat meat and plants.

author: Mathieu Lamontagne

text:
¬†@Mathieu Lamontagne¬† It's propaganda because it uses false information. It doesn't matter whether people have good intention. Meat causing cancer has been debunked. Too much of anything is bad. At least most of time. There is a man who rather lost weight with meat centered diet. He claimed that problem with modern meat is livestock feed and factory farming. The problem is antibiotic and feeding corn. Also those studies showing link between meat and cancer are not showing full pictures. They generally have poor examples. How many of those people ate healthy whole food? It turns out that those Americans use processed junk food. That's the problem. Vegan can suffer from the same processed food, too. 
I respect vegan intention and goal. I agree that meat consumption, especially in developed countries like US needs to be reduced. Fortunately, people already started taking less meat last few years, but this year, meat consumption is expected to rise. I agree that there are many problems with modern animal agriculture, especially factory farming, but just painting every animal agriculture with the same bad practice is hasty generalization. Also, calling for the entire world to go vegan is naive and impractical. Actually, it's inefficient because not everyone thrives on vegan diet, not to mention many parts of the world can't support farming. (Science may be work around that. We will see.) People with longest life span rely on non vegan style. 
Actually, supporting edible bug is better. You know why? Bugs can thrive on tons of food waste and effectively convert them to nutrition. Fruits and vegetables result in tons of food waste even before going to shelf. So why not use bugs like black soldier flies to get rid of them and convert them to protein? Or simply feed those maggots to chickens. It is proven that insect feed is very efficient for raising livestock. They take way less space, too. Even better than plant protein if you want to talk about efficiency. 
There are many ways to tackle environmental problems. It's not always black and white.

text:
I don't doubt cultivating and transporting meat has an enormous impact on our environment.  But is it really true that the 1 billion tons of animal feed is directly translatable to human consumable food?  I hear this point brought up all the time, but never see this claim substantiated.  I've heard of peanut hulls and egg shells being used in animal feed, which are clearly not suitable for human consumption.  And what about hay?

The only paper I could find concerning this matter was "Animal Feed vs. Human Food: Challenges and Opportunities in Sustaining Animal Agriculture Toward 2050", published by The Council for Agricultural Science and Technology in 2013.  It calls this feed-to-food claim into question, especially when it comes to how animal livestock are utilized in  less-developed countries, which have the highest rate of population growth, greatly benefit from livestock as sources of fertilizer and high-quality protein, and also lack the infrastructure to store and transport cereal crops.

Have ya'lls read this, or know of other materials which speak to this point?  Unsurprisingly, a lot of the meat lobby types have taken this paper up, but the paper itself seems pretty impartial and well-researched.

text:
Is this a joke? I cannot even bear to watch this entire video for fear that it actually is NOT a joke. So, with that said, the important questions:

1. How do anthropogenic Carbon Dioxide emissions explain the end of the last Ice Age (roughly 11,700 years ago)?

Assuming your answer is "they don't," i.e., accurate:
2. How do "Climate Change models" mathematically control for whatever forces DID cause Ice Age(s) to come and go repeatedly between 1 million and 20,000 years Before the Present?

Assuming your answer is "they don't," i.e., accurate:
3. Why do you assume the forces which have caused dramatic climate fluctuations in Earth's climate during the past million years can simply be omitted from models which intend to account for human influences on contemporary climate?

4. What about other factors besides human forces?

I have yet to encounter a single individual who espouses "climate change alarm" notions who has been able to succinctly, sincerely, and completely answer these questions.

text:
This is such one-dimensional advice. Could you please also talk about how changing our diet to a more "Mediterranean" diet would affect other aspects of humanity on a global scale?

This video ignores taking into account: price (calories / dollar), global economic impact (i.e. stealing all the quinoa from every native quinoa-eating country), and local availability. Sure, it's nice to say "wow it'd be optimal if everyone ate lentils and rice for every meal". When the rice and lentils are being shipped fully around the globe to be processed and then delivered to our local grocery, the carbon emissions start to look a lot different than just eating your local farmer's beef, if that's available. And fish? seriously? Used to like Vox, but this is the kind of half-assed sensionalist "wow look at this new science" that makes me want to vomit up all the delicious steak I just consumed.

text: There are many different fish that are good and bad, but a lot of what fish is safe or not safe depends on where you live. Part of it also depends on how the fish is caught. You can find lots of online resources, like this: http://seafood.edf.org/guide/best. Where I live, farmed arctic char, clams, mussels, and oysters, Rainbow Trout that are U.S. farmed are just a few good fish to eat. The three things you have to think about are how the fish is caught, what type of fish, and where it is from. A great website to use is seafoodwatch.org! I hope this helps you pick out the best fish!

text:
A Mediterranean diet is similar to a vegetarian diet, but both are different from a a plant based diet, which in itself is distinct from veganism. All vegans are plant based; not all plant based people are vegan. Veganism is a philosophy that rejects the commodification of animals and the notion that they are resources, instead of individual beings with emotions, personalities, and needs. Both the Mediterranean diet and lacto-ovo-vegetarianism allow for the exploitation of animals and therefore don't fall under the vegan umbrella.

As for the environmental aspect of veganism, I recommend anyone interested watch Cowspiracy, available on Netflix. It goes into a lot of detail about what animal agriculture does to our planet.

text:
lefthandovRA It's not just desertification, but land degradation. And desertification doesn't just come from lack of rain fall. Researchers name 2 forms of desertification, one by climate and the other by man-made forces. The one I'm talking about is the 2nd type. In ranges where rainfall remained consistent, large patches & areas of desertification appeared sporadically near areas that had stable grasses. What they found was that desertification appeared most around domesticated overgrazing. This can be observed the most in the Middle East where overgrazing existed for far more centuries. And we're following the same pattern in both North & South America. Cattle are not a native animal, they were imported & domesticated here. Like any new species introduced into an ecosystem, it drove out competitors like Buffalo & Bison which are now an endangered species. 

The difference between water irrigation for rice and drought for rice and meat is huge. For almonds, the researchers at the University of California show almonds to require 23 gallons for an ounce of almonds compared to 106 gallons for an ounce of beef. Not to mention that lb for lb, nobody eats rice and almonds as much as they eat meat. That's hardly a fair comparison, especially considering that 1 lb of meat requires 2500 to 5,000 gallons of water (depending on your sources). 

"Some" of what I listed was transportation? Are you kidding, I listed transportation once. The rest were based on machinery, factory, production, and packaging. And even if avocados were to be transported, they're not on the same level of demand as animals. Bc we're not just transporting animals, but also the soy & grain we fly & boat in from the 3rd world lands to feed livestock. And yes, that grain you mentioned as a cause of deforestation, that grain is fed to livestock. 

And I never said that deforested lands were part of the food market trade. I said corporate land grabs of 3rd world countries were. Those corporate farms interfere with the land ownership & market competition of local farmers in 3rd world countries. Many of them go bankrupt, many workers are traded in exchange for machinery & go into poverty. 

Back to the drought dilemma, California alone sends 100 billion gallons of water in alfalfa to Asian countries where we import livestock. That's alot of water & fuel used to export out & export back in. Hardly an efficient way to produce food. Continued below....
author: YourMajesty143
YourMajesty143

text:
YourMagesty, if you're going to play copy & paste, I'll follow :) That's complete & utter BULLSHIT YourMajesty! To the point that you are blaming animals for stuff that is in fact the fault of vegan eating & that properly managed animal farming fixes!
Chemical fertiliser run off causes ocean deadzones, NOT animal agriculture! 1/3rd of the world's arable land has been destroyed in the 40 years since chemicals replaced animals, Indonesia is the biggest deforester/wildlife extinguisher & that's ALL to grow VEGAN alternative to meat products (palm & rubber trees) etc etc etc! complete bullshit for your entire post!
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
lefthandovRA, "Thats not how desertification works you cant turn an area into a desert,that depends mainly on rain fall." actually bad land management can lead to desertification in areas with enough rain that they shouldn't be desert. The Loss (sorry, can't spell) plateau in China is the classic example of that & the vegans go to example of how it's possible to plant trees in "deserts". It's actually fertilie land, that they grazed & grew crops on in ridiculous ways & turned it to desert.

Crops are the worst for desertifying, because they plow the land & then leave it bare waiting for rain, which leads to massive erosion & so then the rain can't get properly absorbed. The solution is to plant anything that will grow into that land to hold it together (normally perennial native grasses), however grass is a high nitrogen user, so if you don't get some fertilsier in there, then it will die off & again you get desertification. The best solution, therefore is to get the native grasses in, then once they're mature & have seed, send a big mob of animals in for a single day to prune them down to the ground & thoroughly fertilise, then move the animals off to a new area, carrying the seed with them & send the animals back once it's mature again. That's refered to as "holistic grazing" & is having HUGE success in reversing desertified areas of fertile & semi-arid land. Video showing the results https://youtu.be/vpTHi7O66pI?t=984

& there's natually methane eating bacteria in the soil & in that system they thrive too & so there's no need to geneticly modify the cows to stop them producing it (in fact there's no evidence ruminents have EVER had ANY influence on methane levels in the atmosphere http://www.amazingcarbon.com/PDF/JONES-CarbonFriendlyBeef(27April10).pdf )
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
+YourMajesty143, your patience and willingness to spread good knowledge is incredibly admirable. I hope you find the strength to do this as often as you can. We can only hope it makes a difference, but I do believe it does.

+LilacLizard I agree that chemical fertilizers can cause the deadzones you mentioned, but YourMajesty143's argument was that improper disposal of the HUGE amounts of waste produced by livestock farming can lead to similar results. And palm trees and rubber trees have never been marketed as a meat substitute? Again, it is undeniable that the environmental damage caused by the palm tree industry in Indonesia is staggering, but that's a completely different topic. Lastly, all forms of agriculture, from meat farming to crop farming, can lead to soil erosion. It's all about doing it responsibly.
author: Connor Moen

text:
Connor, the amount of animal waste you are talking about is worth a fortune! It doesn't get flushed away! Fertilisers are generally government subsidised & cost next to nothing, so farmers use the "more-on" approach anytime something isn't growing properly & smother it with moron chemicals. There is also legislation in all developed world counties (where the vast majority of CAFO's are located that prohibit improper management of waste as a health hazard. It's pure bullshit to claim nitrogen runoff in the ocean is coming from animals not nitrogen applied as fertiliser!

palm oil is used in a range of products, but most meat eaters know that animal based products blend best with human skin. It's vegans who want animal free alternatives & palm oil provides that. Vegans are also creating so much lobbying that even though their numbers are small, a disproportionate number of products are changing ingredients in order to be able to label themselves as "vegan", which is why there is so much demand for palm oil! Vegan are FAR more responsible for deforestation than meat eaters are! & as for rubber, maybe you can explain to me what your using to replace leather & sheepskin in your shoes & slippers if not rubber from those plantations?

& lastly, if we look at irresponsible farming practices, we see crops are the worst in a huge range of ways, if we look at average farming of both, we see MASSIVE run off & wind errosion in crops, particularly in climate change situations, while we so NO runoff with livestock. If we look at best possible practice on both, we see that there is no way to avoid run off & erosion in a large variety of settings, other than perennial grasses - which are therefore only suitable for livestock farming & significantly reduce available agricultural land on the planet if not used as such (from 37% of the earth's surface to 10% of the earth's surface) & therefore we very rarely see best practice in crop farming in the world today! On the other hand, when we look at best practice livestock management, we see massive land regeneration & reversal of desertification & massive increases in soil carbon, leading to increased water retention, reduced run off & massive soild biliding - in fact the ONLY way to restore the 1/3rd of the world's croplands that have been destroyed by chemical fertilisers is by converting that land to pasture & using years of animals on the land to restore it (although again, when we switch to best practice, some farmers are acheiving restoration of land with NOTHING that will grow to full productive pasture within 12 months - still 5-10 years to flush the chemical fertiliser salts out & build up enough carbon to grow crops again without needing extensive chemical fertilsier, herbicides & pesticides though

There are more organisms in a single handful of healthy soil than there are humans who have ever lived on this planet! Chemical fertilsier kills them all! There can be near to zero in that 1/3rd of land I'm talking about as destroyed. Livestock in high enough concentrations can poop out enough organisms to repopulate & restore teh soil eco-system, so it can begin carbon sequencing again, but until those livestock are added, it will do nothing but loose soil & add to global warming as all that carbon leaves the ground & enters the air.

Eco-systems do NOT survive with chemicals replacing animals, like vegans want to see!

author: DJ BEAXS

text:
DJ Beaxs, here's a list of what makes up the 6billion tonnes of food that livestock on the planet eat every year http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/home/en/news_archive/photo/2017_Infografica_6billion.jpg almost half is grass & leaves & another 20% is crop waste, so none of that will reduce without livestock, the grass & leaves will still grow & in fact the most common way other than livestock to deal with overgrown grass & fallen leaves is to burn it off, which causes even more greenhouse gasses, since ALL carbon is reconverted into CO2

There's lots of livestock in the wrong places on the planet right now, but seasonal grasslands (semi-arid/almost desert areas, like you see in the savanna in Africa) actually require grazing animals of some kind for the eco-systems to function correctly. Those areas are too dry for the fungus etc that break down organic matter in rainforests, so ruminant animals doing it is the only option in nature. 37% of the planet's surface is currently in use for agriculture, but only 10% of that is capable of supporting any level of crop production, the rest can only support animals & is the type of land I just described, so I really don't think removing the animals would help, it would just lead to more grass fires. 

If we could return natural grazing animals to the land, that might be different, but I can't see that happening & it wouldn't change the methane output anyway.

Shutting down factory farming is a different story! Taking animals out of those feedlots, no longer growing crops to feed animals, just putting them in the right place - on those semi-arid areas & feeding them just on the grass that grows there would definitely reduce methane levels, especially since dung beetles bury the dung & then soil bacteria break down the methane into harmless elements in those settings

text: So, this video discussion is thrown off by the fact that it is looking at global greenhouse sources rather then US global greenhouse sources. The EPA has the US Agriculture accounting for 9% of US greenhouse gases and 27% from transportation. This is simply because basically everyone in the US drives and eats, while about 1 in 6 people drive globally, but everyone eats. If you go from "average American" to vegan American, you might see about an 7-8% drop in the greenhouse gas emotions, not nothing, but also not massive. If you change from an average American car to an very fuel efficient car, you half your part of the 27% from transportation which is 63% of that, so you reduce your greenhouse gases by 8.5%. If you go to electric car, you drop about 14%. Though the issue with cars is that the amount of greenhouse gas to make a car, it is close to driving a car 40,000 miles to get the same CO2 it is to make an average car.

text:
to everybody saying that veganism is better, we get it. veganism does save resources such as water and reduce CO2 emissions.

However, veganism also takes away land from ecosystems, like forests and woods in which animals like goats are bred in. It consumes much more land because much more crops are consumed per day than meat (you probably eat around 200% more grain than chicken a day).

Not only that, but many vegans consume market oil, which is developed from animal fat; animal fats are also used industrially very commonly. To take away these animal fats would require new replacements to be developed, which is costly and isnt always doable.

Veganism has its arguments, and it has its counterarguments. If somebody doesn't want to be vegan or does, it's their choice, and you have no right to enforce what you don't even know is truly beneficial to the world on somebody else.

text: Jason Peng Actually alot of livestock are raised on grain. It takes about 1/16th the land to grow plants to feed humans directly than it does to feed livestock which are then fed to humans. Not to mention the inefficient use of resources. Why filter my grains through a corpse when I can eat my nutrients directly at a fraction of the cost? Also, meat is incredibly resource-intensive. It's more than just methane & carbon emissions. Animal agriculture uses 1/3 of the world's water, 1/3 of the world's fuel, cause desertification of the land, soil depletion, and dumps massive amounts of fecal waste into our waterways (leading to hypoxic dead zones). Let's not forget the deforestation, displacement of indigenous ppl, 3rd world starvation due to corporate land grabs & manipulation of food trade prices, wildlife extinction bc the cattle industry lobbies for hunting mandates that kill off land competitors, sealife extinction bc of the excessively exploited fishing & due to the fact that cattle are fed fish pellets. There's also the matter of our taxes paying all the subsidies for meat. If we cut out meat, it would create an economic boom for us bc we'd reduce the amount of taxes & allocate them towards infrastructure or allow us to generate consumer spending towards other industries.

author: Eva Weir

text:
Eva, I haven't seen that last study before, but great find! I think that NAILS the problems & solutions! I haven't read the others yet, but I would trust the FAO over the others, since they're the ones really in the front line figuring out how to feed the entire global populaiton & that link states

_"Globally, there is enough cropland to feed 9 billion in 2050 if the 40 percent of all crops produced today for feeding animals were used directly for human consumption, while available grasslands were more efficiently used as the basis for livestock feed. Grassland-based and mixed crop-livestock systems optimize nutrient and energy cycles, while encouraging the use of rare livestock breeds that are adapted to 
 lowinput and harsh environments. This is crucial in a context of climate change and increasing variability. "_

So they're saying that we still need meat to feed that number of people, but we need to put animals where they belong - on land too dry to grow crops!

Just another comment on an extra point it made, about currently 33% of croplands used for animals, that's not always what it seems! I live in Australia, the UN states that 1% of the continent of Australia is suitable for growing continuous crops. Around 8-10% of the continent can be used up to once a year in good seasons, if given periods of rest/stock grazing in between crops. It's normal however for much of that land to fail to produce for up to a decade due to droughts, providing only low intensity livestock grazing (often including the livestock being fed the crops intended for human consumption that have failed due to drought). 

All that land would fall within that 33% they talk about as arable land, but it requires livestock on it in order to remain arable. In fact, 1/3rd of the planet's arable land has been lost in the last 40 years since chemical fertilisers were introduced, much of this could be salvaged with long term managed grazing to restore it, but more importantly, rotating grazing into land heading down this path, can rescue it before it's lost & maintain it's productivity long term.

Extra point on this, 70% of Australia is used for farming of livestock - land that cannot be used for anything else, in fact people like the UN & other "experts" don't believe it's possible to get anywhere near 70% of the continent as agricultural land, saying 50% at most, due to more than that being termed as arid/desert land. The most sustainable agriculture in Australia is actually wild kangaroo harvesting (which is required for the health of the kangaroos & the land, since humans have been the only apex predator on the continent for 30,000 years & the entire eco-system would collapse if their roo culling was ended - was tested in 2002, after a few years of no culling due to animal welfare people successfully lobbying for it to end & 1/3rd of the roo population, 18million of them starved as a result, with countless other species also suffering & dying in mass numbers because of the roos eating everything as they died)
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
Eva, just finished reading your other 2 links, great resourses! Where did you find them & do you have anymore to share? I think we're on the same page on this stuff :)) Lets add to those articles ending food waste too & not only going organic, but looking at crop natural suitability to regions & through varieties chosen (which the livestock link covered, but on crops too, eg painted mountain corn instead of regular or GM corn) Sorghum for example is far more drought tolerant than corn (that's what's used in Australia if crops are grown for animals), NASA's found 8 varieties of potatoes that they believe can grow on Mars - no GM, just looking at available natural varieties growing in harsh conditions on earth.

We've got to get corperations & seeking out ways to make profit out of our food & return to connecting with nature & working with her instead of fighting her to produce our food! & we need to get some common sense back into food & farming choices!
author: Lilac Lizard

text:
I see culling as a necessity different than raising and slaughtering livestock for the purpose of consumption (but then what to do with the culled meat... hmm. pet cat and dog food?). And I think most kangaroo predators were actually hunted to extinction within the last 100 years or so by settlers, humans alone would not have been able to keep that large of a kangaroo population down haha. Same thing almost happened with deer and moose here in Minnesota, USA. Another problem caused by human shortsightedness.

https://www.nature.com/articles/ncomms11382#results this journal is associated with Scientific American

(from the researchgate link)
"Hunger is caused by poverty and inequality, not scarcity... According to the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations the world produces more than 1 1/2 times enough food to feed everyone on the planet. That‚Äôsalready enough to feed 10 billion people, the world‚Äôs 2050 projected pop-ulation peak. But the people making less than $2 a day‚Äîmost of whomare resource-poor farmers cultivating un-viably small plots of land‚Äîcannot afford to buy this food."  This quote is not even including animal agriculture. The issue is greedy corporations and governments, as you say, not scarcity.


My main concern is that a high-meat diet is also linked with affluence, and that the demand for meat products is rising. If people living in areas that can  eat vegan do so, this could dampen the effects of animal agriculture in areas where veganism is not feasible with current agriultural and political trends. Veganism may not be accessible at the moment in parts of the world, BUT most of US/EU/AU definitely have the resources, thanks to globalization. It still is not the best answer ethically, environmentally, or for public health.

author: Tayler Baker

text:
Last non-human roo predators were the Thylacoleonidae family (marsupial lions, which interestingly are believed to have begun life as herbivores & switched to carnivores to fill the niche) & Mekosuchine (terrestrial crocodiles), both of which were megafauna that went extinct 30,000 years ago, possibly as a result of humans, possibly not, humans co-existed with them for 30,000 years before they went extinct. Tassy tiger is in the marsupial lion family, it was hunted to extinction by white man within 100 years, but it's biggest prey was a possum & even that is debated as to if it could take one alive or only scavenge. It never took human sized roos. Aboriginals numbered up to 1 million when whites arrived & they farmed animals like roos and crops, but in such harmony with the land that whites didn't even realise the crops weren't natural (and didn't want to, spoilt their propaganda that the land was uninhabited).

Dingos do take a few, especially smaller wallabies, but they're not actually natives, they were introduced around 4,000 years ago. Impossible to say how the eco-system would function with them & not humans, since it's never happened, but mammals aren't natural here, only marsupials are, so it's likely not smart to try, especially since roos can live in the desert & dingos can't, so likely would end up a mess. Rewilding in Yellowstone etc is another story, since those predators were naturally there (and isn't that a success story! - which shouldn't really be surprising)

& uneaten by human roo meat becomes pet food, but it's worth less, so shooters get paid less & are therefore of a lower skill level & make more mistakes. Assessments on human food culled roos show a really high levels of shooting accuracy & male only killing. Basically, the higher the value of the meat, the higher the animal welfare that goes with the kills. If the pet food market falls through, then the bodies are left to rot in paddocks & those ones are shot by amateur farmers, who often miss, often accidentally shoot mothers with young & while it's still better than some of the footage we get to see of their starving (maggots being laid under the skin of living animals & eating them alive once they're too weak to fend them off), the more we humans eat & the higher the meat value goes, the higher the shooter skill level & animal welfare checks (all shooters have tags that must be accounted for, human shooter tags are checked to ensure every kill was a clean, single shot to the brain)

It still kinda yucks me out to be eating "skippy", but it is the most ethical meat eating option & does improve their welfare. I'd rather eat them than watch the news footage we saw back in 2002 again!!!!!!!!!!!

"This quote is not even including animal agriculture. The issue is greedy corporations and governments, as you say, not scarcity." that's the 40% of food we produce in the west & then dispose of, mostly because it wasn't up to "cosmetic standards" smh! INSANE! (plus the other stuff that report spoke of with using it for fuel etc)

"If people living in areas that can  eat vegan do so" I'd prefer to see us use our influence to experiment with agriculture & learn more effective techniques that provide the highest possible level of animal welfare & then share these. There's no such thing as grain fed meat in Australia anymore, you have to special order it, due to a campaign to switch, for health & animal welfare reasons. That imo makes much more difference to overall animal welfare than a small percentage of people going vegan, since effectively all feedlots were shut down. 

The more people demanding grass fed, the more pressure on those systems & the more chance farmers will switch to the holistic farming model that was in your first FAO link, which then sees huge land improvements & productivity improvements & can easily be implemented in third world countries with few resourses. The other thing is that a HUGE amount of Australia's income comes from meat sales internationally. Remove that & we would have only mining left to make money. Is it really more ethical to be selling uranium & coal when compared to animals? Because with all of those removed, Australia becomes third world! I'd rather accept that income BUT not accept it in it's full & without question! We ship animals overseas, where they then enter feedlots & suffer incredibly cruel treatment! The industry says it's essential & the country can't afford to loose that income, well I don't accept that! I'll accept the meat industry, but NOT substandard treatment of animals, with an out of sight, out of mind attitude! I don't believe there's any necessity to put any animal on a ship alive! It's cruel & there's alternatives, we just need to push for them!!!!!!!

gtg for now, will read those links later & reply some more I'm sure. I can't believe your getting them from vegan sites! My experience with vegan links is normally pure propaganda easily proven as completely wrong, but you've got some really great stuff that really looks at root causes & tries to find genuine solutions or at least recognises facts & truths about the world - I don't like our chances of ever beating the big money, but we can damwell try & give it everything we've got! :))

text: 2sudonim ok but how do you think a whole makes a change? It happens first by individuals. Change occurs by many chains of cause and effect. How do you think the voting system works? Your argument is basically invalidating democracy if you think that what one person thinks makes no difference. It's not possible for a whole group to think exactly the same, change happens first with individuals. The only way a "systematic change" can occur is if it has support, and the only way to garner support is if those ideas are already out there. Individual actions do make an impact, and videos like these are examples how those actions and ideas can be spread to make a greater difference.
author: sesi

text:
@Sesi Lui TL;DR Fads and competitive consumption are not the path to lasting change.

"ok but how do you think a whole makes a change? It happens first by individuals. Change occurs by many chains of cause and effect. How do you think the voting system works? Your argument is basically invalidating democracy if you think that what one person thinks makes no difference."

One vote doesn't make a difference. That's plainly obvious. Individuals don't matter in Democracy; coalitions are what matter in Democracies. That's why parties, caucuses within those parties, and special interest groups have such great power within our system. It's why community organizing is such a powerful tool.

Atomized, consumerist notions of politics is what let Nader throw the election to Bush in 2000, and Berners throw the election to Trump in 2016. Because white Americans have been trained to view everything through the lens of consumerism and individualism instead of the collectivism and community action that actually brings the power in effect change.

The sooner you and everyone who thinks like you learns this, the better we'll all be.

"It's not possible for a whole group to think exactly the same, change happens first with individuals. The only way a "systematic change" can occur is if it has support, and the only way to garner support is if those ideas are already out there. Individual actions do make an impact, and videos like these are examples how those actions and ideas can be spread to make a greater difference."

That's not how change happens. Ever. It has literally never happened that way in human history. Systematic change requires collective action to change systems. That's so obvious it's almost a tautology. It's why vegan-vegetarianism makes up >1% of the population. It's why collective organizations, like corporations and trade groups, have been able to effect regulator capture and subsidies while sustainable living has not. It's how the organic foods movement managed to be so easily appropriated and perverted by agribusiness. It's why cash crops like corn and soy beans, half of which get fed to animals for meat production, have huge subsidies while fruits and vegetables don't.

Your not eating meat doesn't lead to a single less animal being raised. It doesn't lead to a single drop of water being saved. It doesn't lead to a single gram of carbon being prevented from being released into the atmosphere. It can't. The concept of a carbon footprint is a statistical abstraction, not an actual thing. Individuals reducing their carbon footprint doesn't actually reduce the amount of carbon being emitted by our civilization. It's only when statistically significant percentages of the population undertake change that any real world effects take place.

text: 2sudonim but it's not a single person going vegan/ vegetarian?? There are more now, at this point in history, than ever before. Change is happening, I don't know why you're trying to deny it, especially if it makes such a positive impact on the environment

author: N. Alkmim

text:
Some simple tips to eating less meat once in a while:
1. Replace beef in chili or tacos for beans, add extra garlic and/or onions for extra flavor. 
2. Do a veggie pot pie (use veggie broth and no meat), super easy to replace! 
3. Don't get bacon or sausage on your breakfast sandwich, an egg & cheese is still good! 
4. Restaurants usually don't have an issue with you swapping the meat in the dish for something else. ex) Instead of chicken on your Greek wrap, get falafel or artichokes or extra cheese (never pay more to swap for basic veggies! The meat is the most expensive part!) 
5. A lot of "meat products" (like "beef" burritos) use textured vegetable protein as a filler and it's really good on it's own! Soak it in water then crisp up in a sauce pan with spices, super easy! I do this a lot for chili, shepherd's pie, etc 
6. Some "meat products" actually aren't, like some beef burritos (said above) or bacon bits. Read the labels, you'd be surprised!
7. I found ground beef to be the easiest meat to replace in recipes (except for burgers of course, you can't replace a good cheeseburger!) 

No shame in eating meat, it's natural for humans. But every effort counts, even if you just eat vegetarian once in a while. Glad you read my tips and I hope it helps!

text: Calm that DOWN Inconclusive. Many anthropologists argue against this notion. There's nothing special or unique about meat that would stimulate evolution. Many theorize it was the discovery of fire. The brains preferred source of fuel is glucose, and cooking caused the breakdown of starches and cellular walls which allowed for easier digestion, quicker nutrient assimilation, and a reduced amount of food-borne illnesses. This is far more logical and aligns with how evolution works, since it wasn't the chemical composition of the food that created adaptation, but the change in its structure. And I'm ok with lab-griwn meat. It's not healthy at all, but at least no animal dies & the planet isn't harmed.

I'm against veganism, which is obviously unhealthy. Neither fruits nor vegetables are "natural" per se. They are man made GMO's that came about from the cultivation of agriculture. text: Obviously reduction in meat consumption would be a fantastic way to go, I despise steak and other heavy meats, only like ground beef on occasion. But a lot of these statistics are off. The U.S produces a vast majority of its own food, in the U.S, 9% of pollution is from agriculture, including livestock. Transportation is 28%, that's almost a 4 fold difference. Not to mention the U.S is by far the largest agricultural giant in the world, and consumes massive amounts of meat. I would however note, quite a lot of livestock eat food we cannot, such as grass. And wildly processed corn that doesn't do us much good, and in areas where other plants like beans can't grow year round. Accounting for pollution for agriculture has far too many variables, that aren't always accounted for.

author: Daniel Marynak

text:
So is everyone hearing here ‚Äúeat no more meat just go vegan‚Äù? Because that‚Äôs not at all what the video said.

They mention how eating meat DAILY is the issue. Moreso that we prefer slower growing, gassier animals like cows to eat. Chicken has like 1/4 of the methane emissions per pound compared to Cow; fish even less.

If we found a way to fit in meals that cut back on our meat consumption, ones that we enjoy. I think over time we would find plant-based meals can be just as much of a comfort food. 

There‚Äôs no replacing your Grandma‚Äôs roast beef recipe, but you can make things like it a real special occasion when you don‚Äôt eat it once every week or so.

Please don‚Äôt think I‚Äôm someone who follows this advice yet. I live with four people who I share meals with and convincing them requires a total upheaval of what they expect to eat for dinner and even lunch and breakfast. We all grew up with meat as the ‚ÄúAll American‚Äù thing.

The thing we all CAN share even if we‚Äôre not Americans is to say ‚ÄúI care about our planet and I want to see human‚Äôs impact on its climate reduced.‚Äù That is something you can change. 

If we simply talk to people and you work to change habits over time, we can all do this together.
