author: KT Nicolau

text:
Oye Carb Theoretically you can just consider every steak you buy to be an investment someone else has already made in creating every other part of that cow. Buying more beef to try and ‚Äúcull the numbers‚Äù just creates a bigger demand and more cows to be grown in the future. 

It was grown to age and then slaughtered. It was flayed open, organs removed, and drained of blood. Then it‚Äôs off to a shop where it gets sectioned and cut. After that, ‚Äúhigh quality‚Äù cuts are less than 1/4 of the total meat yielded.

Every steak you buy is the end result of a cow‚Äôs entire life, that includes everything it‚Äôs ever eaten, every plant it‚Äôs ever stepped on, and of course...all the times it has pooped, farted, or belched. THOSE are the emissions we care about.

All the wasted byproducts are extremely easy to measure in small quantities, but there is quite a lot of time passing and a lot of those byproducts are made. (READ: cows belch, fart, and poop a lot. They‚Äôre really inefficient at digesting, which is why they eat everything multiple times)

So, while there are ways that we can reduce the damage it does to the land to actually bring cows out to pasture. It‚Äôs probably not really much less methane emissions when compared to raising a cow in much more inhumane conditions.

If you ignore all of the talk about why we don‚Äôt like the downsides to our system of obtaining meat...there is still the problem of how much of it goes to waste. I can attest to cooking and throwing out the leftovers of much larger meals than I need to. Yet it feels easier to just buy more food than to eat ALL the leftovers myself.

EDIT: To more directly answer your point, we should just eat meats in general LESS OFTEN. Don‚Äôt feel guilty about your steak unless it personally bothers you that an animal was specifically raised and slaughtered for your dinner to reach your plate.

People around the world farm-raise livestock of all kinds for their meat. Cows, chicken, fish, pigs, sheep, and goats are just most of the examples.

Nobody can say that we should forsake our culture as humans without having to answer ‚Äúwhy is that something worth changing?‚Äù And that‚Äôs always something related to personal identity. 

Let‚Äôs all just enjoy that we have different opinions and try harder to be conscious about the impact we have on the world and people around us.

text:
Oye Carb - there is currently a disproportionate amount of animals being bred for food. if cows weren't bred in such large quantities and were part of the outside ecosystem there would be less of them and they would have a better quality of life, also the overall levels of methane would be lower. 

another environmental benefit of eating less animals or none at all / abolishing production of animal products are there would be less deforestation to make room for the animals and all the grains that they eat. when you breed animals for food you are growing the plants to feed them so that they can grow and then you can eat the animal once it has matured to give you the most meat. when you stop that, you only have to grow the plant foods that go directly to us. it is technically more efficient in terms of land use therefore has a greatly reduced environmental impact 

with the fish i guess if you were to cut back all your meat consumption to only fish as some people do, it would reduce the damage to the environment you would have contributed to. but the oceans are also being depleted of fish because of our consumption of fish and is wiping out whole species of fish such as cod which causes an imbalance in the food web of marine life. fish that ate cod find it harder to find enough of them and their population is decreasing out of starvation, fish that were eaten by cod are not being eaten as much because there are less cod and their population is increasing. this imbalance has a butterfly effect on the whole ecosystem. 

the ocean is also warming and becoming more acidic and far reaching changes caused by simply overfishing one species in one part of the ocean will make our ocean unrecognisable if we don't change what we're doing. if the water is warmer, the weather system will become more unstable and there will be more storms because the temperature of the water affects the atmosphere above. 

one way to protect the environment is to stop producing and eating animal products

text:
MRTN13 I hadn‚Äôt considered the sustainability of shrimp farming...and as much as I‚Äôm creeped out by the idea of eating bugs, I know it‚Äôs mostly to do with not having tried eating bugs at all, let alone well prepared.

Until recently I also wouldn‚Äôt eat fish on the same principle, I ignored that I would eat fishsticks, or breaded and fried shrimp and enjoy them, and only focus on the times I found it to be undesirable.

One thing I couldn‚Äôt see the world doing is even trying to go vegan until we can give up things like eggs, honey, ALL MILK PRODUCTS(this one kills me inside thinking of, as I enjoy the flavor of things made with cream, cheese and butter).

Baked good exist in every single culture. I wonder what kind of foods would exist in a mostly vegan one. Is there anything exploitative about baking soda?

Not that it would be very relevant, if you take the idea of being vegan for morality‚Äôs sake then you have to seriously question if you consider plants life and if you‚Äôre exploiting them by killing them for harvest, and only occasionally continuing their family genetics.

We clone plants to increase the genetic representation of a trait we want. Like how we have all of a certain avocado(Haas?) being cloned from the same plant, I forget all the details. There is also technology being developed to let all organisms express genes differently, forcibly.

Where do we draw the line through the shades of gray?

What could everyone who isn‚Äôt in with or actually a politician themselves do to save Net Neutrality? I‚Äôve contacted my representatives in Congress and they‚Äôre all historically against something like the repeal. And yet I feel as though I‚Äôm trying to fight the wind itself by blowing back at it.

text: In the last year how much coal do you think we burned? According to the Institute for Energy research ‚ÄúThe United States produces nearly 1.1 billion short tons of coal a year, making it the world‚Äôs second largest coal producer. China produces over 3.5 billion short tons a year.‚Äù That‚Äôs a total of 4.6 billion short tons total which is equal to 4.08*1012 kg or 4.08 trillion kg of C burned a year. If we convert that into moles and then that into kgs we get 1.5*1013 kg or 15 trillion kg of CO2 produced a year by the US and China ALONE.Hopefully at this point you are convinced that humans produce a lot of CO2.
author: Sasquatchan Bearhunter

text:
Section 4 Connecting it to Global warming:
Hopefully at this point you are convinced that humans produce a lot of CO2 but you may be asking so what? Well in order to understand how CO2 is affecting the environment you first have to understand what a greenhouse gas is and how it warms up the atmosphere. Here is a link explaining what it is http://www.dnrec.delaware.gov/climatechange/pages/greenhouse%20effect.aspx If you don‚Äôt want to read that link here is a decent explanation. 

Basically when solar radiation enters the Earth‚Äôs atmosphere it does so mostly in the form of visible light (The yellow light we see). When that enters the atmosphere and hits the surface of the Earth, it is absorbed. The earth then emits this same energy it absorbed in the form of infrared radiation back into the atmosphere. Without any greenhouse gases the IR radiation would just pass through the atmosphere and back into space. However, when greenhouse gases such as CO2 are in the atmosphere some of the heat is absorbed by the gas molecules and then sent back to the Earth‚Äôs surface. Some of this effect is a good thing as it keeps Earth warmer than freezing cold and keeps the temperature fairly even throughout the globe. However too much of the CO2 ¬†and you get too much warming and it has adverse effects. Currently that‚Äôs what is happening. We humans are pumping too much CO2 into the environment causing too much of the greenhouse effect and thereby warming the planet too much. 

If you want to understand how the IR energy/radiation is absorbed by you need a bit of chemistry knowledge. Conceptually when a molecule absorbs IR radiation the bonds of the molecule to stretch or bend until eventually the IR radiation is re-emitted back towards the earth essentially trapping the IR radiation within the atmosphere. This is the greenhouse gas effect. Only certain molecules can absorb IR radiation. These molecules have dipoles (difference in charges between atoms) between bonds. This enables the stretching and bending of the intramolecular bonds.
author: Sasquatchan Bearhunter

I just kind of dislike the general strategy of trying to get individual people to change their diet to help. Obviously, it makes a difference - but only on the macro level. Like, if I decide not to have meat half the time - and me alone - it probably won't reduce carbon emissions... it'll probably just mean that meat I would have eaten will get thrown out... 

Sure, it's good... but I guess I just feel like we need to do something way more radical than just... trying to make some people change their diet. Like, how about actually making a LAW about how much meat can be made, so the change is immediate and people are forced to change their diet?

text: toknowandgrow Bc the reduced consumption will reduce the demands & hence, further production. It's to stop the cycle of excess breeding. Also It's more than just methane & carbon emissions. Animal agriculture use 1/3 of the world's water, 1/3 of the world's fuel, cause desertification of the land, soil depletion, and dump massive amounts of fecal waste into our waterways (leading to hypoxic dead zones). Let's not forget the deforestation, displacement of indigenous ppl, 3rd world starvation due to corporate land grabs & manipulation of food trade prices, wildlife extinction bc the cattle industry lobbies for hunting mandates that kill off land competitors, sealife extinction bc of the excessively exploited fishing & due to the fact that cattle are fed fish pellets. There's also the matter of our taxes paying all the subsidies for meat. If we cut out meat, it would create an economic boom for us bc we'd reduce the amount of taxes & allocate them towards infrastructure or allow us to generate consumer spending towards other industries.

text:
Really enjoy the openness in these kinds of topics, especially the clear mentioning of perhaps the largest "weirdest" alternative, Veganism. Way to go for plant-power!
    Although we shouldn't enforce going vegan and at least vegetarian, the 90% or more reduction is meat is plausible to advocate now and this is perhaps the only media source I've heard openly addressing this with millions of followers/subscribers. There may be a few other sources also getting on board but when this can be a regular discussion then the ambiguity around this can fall apart leaving just hard pressed arrogance to duel with. 
  I noticed in this episode that they skimmed over the facts here and even left out the specifics (unsurprising) for why the data between vegan, vegetarian and mediterranean seems rather indistinguishable, which may give the misconception to individuals that mediterranean and vegetarian consumption is no different the veganism. "Go have the salmon!", maybe not for long. Of course it's better option than something like beef, but that doesn't have to be the end point. This where detailed facts need to come in, otherwise will be play along to confirmation biases, defense mechanisms and logical fallacies that gets us nowhere closer to a sustainable and more healthful future. 
   We can be sympathetic to cultural ingrained ideologies when it comes to food, but to remain cyclical about it pardons no one when there's a continual stream of access to factual information showing erred in reason. 
A meal a day, a week or two with out animal products is a great first step.

text:
NatureShy If you had to kill the animal first hand, could you do it? I am fully vegan now, but it took me years to finally get there. The final step of my journey was two-fold, that my father-in-law was dying of Alzheimer's disease and my husband had stage 4 Prostate cancer. My father-in-law is now dead and my husband's surgery got all the cancer but we are due for his one year check-up soon in November. Before that, my mother, sister and mother-in-law, all died of breast cancer. 

I had had terrible arthritis in my hands so I gave up all dairy. Whenever I cheated and had cheese on a pizza or ate ice cream, I'd regret it. I started buying veggie burgers for our dog as she was alleging to all grains because of genetically modified foods. Now I enjoy the veggie burgers. I feel more alert, not in a brain fog. I no longer need to take sleep medication to get a full night's sleep. I've lost 35 lbs. I still am losing weight but at age 65, the weight does not come off fast. But it is enough to bring down my cholesterol, never had high blood pressure and my blood sugar is now right where it should be.

You can learn to enjoy your food no matter what it is. Visit a Japanese steak house and order tofu, when it is prepared properly, it is delicious. Or go to an Indian restaurant and ask what are the vegan dishes. Eat those, you will be satisfied.

Now I eat about 1/3 raw and the rest cooked. And I am not tempted to go back to the old way of eating. 

I had to take care of my father with Alzheimer's disease. Our children should not have that sort of burden and if my husband and I take better care of ourselves, we will be there to play with our grand children, not have to join them in diapers because we lost our minds.

What sort of future do you want? The average person at retirement age is on 10 medications. I don't have to take any. I've gotten my husband off of dairy and soda pop, his blood pressure came down on its own, he did not need a the pills. 

He is devoted to eating meat as if to give it up would kill him, actually the opposite is true.

But we prove what we want to prove to ourselves. I studied how I could cure my arthritis and I got hooked on doing research and finding a new adventure in how I could eat to improve my health.

Is your health as important to you as mine is to me? I don't have skin cancer and I have no signs of any kinds of cancer. My sister died as 64, and I am a year older than she lived. She suffered dreadfully. My hope is someday, to go in my sleep being as healthy as possible to my dying day.

author: Mart√≠nSQ

text:
¬†@Mart√≠nSQ¬† First of all, what your talking about is Moral Absolutism. It's the ethical belief that there are absolute standards against which moral questions can be judged and that certain actions are right or wrong, regardless of the context of the act. Almost no ethical philosophers on the planet believe in moral absolutism for good reason. In order for something to be a moral absolute, it has to universally agreed to be either morally right or morally wrong in every possible scenario. No such moral standard exists, because if there exists any gray area then it can't be a moral absolute. Examples: 
1) Stealing is wrong; except when it's to feed your family.
2) Killing is wrong; except when it's in self-defense.
3) Rape is wrong; except in a situation like the Handmaids Tale where only a handful of women could still reproduce and if they don't have sex then humanity will go extinct.


The last one is a bit of a stretch I'll admit, but the point is that if there exists any exceptions then it can't be an absolute.
author: kalzoa

text:
I know what moral absolutism is, and I am not advocating for that in such a strict sense as you present. Of course there are no "Absolute moral truths" if by that you search for something which is absolutelly context-independent. That's because literally nothing in the universe is context-independent. But we here, on Earth, and in our society, have some context (for instance, being alive, or an animal, or a human being) which imply almost all of us will have some atomical "truths" in common which we see as obvious. I'm talking about purely logical and formal truths, which are the necessary bricks of every good argument ever made.
Of course there's not a way to metaphysically dictate that those truths are absolute or even correct. We've just experienced for unnumerable instances that, when facing the world using logic and reason (even the most basic one, like "I want that food, so I'll extend my hand to grab it"), it has come out well.
That's to say, we have a global experience, as sentient beings, of some basic notions about the world which basically all of us can agree on. From there, we can build by reasoning and observing the world.
Saying the vast majority agree on these basic bricks is not to say the vast majority will be right about any moral issue, for the real world and human relations distort our reasoning (and our brain isn't perfect), so we fail in our argumentations a lot (and some issues, we don't even think about).
But given, for instance, that almost all actual people will agree that it's better to maximize pleasure and minimize pain (utilitarian) and that most animals have sentience and feelings, as shown by science, (and both these assumptions are clearly shown by the fact that, for instance, almost all actual people will see unnecessarily beating up a dog as bad), just from those two it's possible to reason, only with basic logical truths, that eating animals is wrong (because, basically, it creates too much pain for them and too little pleasure for us).
author: Mart√≠nSQ

text:
¬†@Mart√≠nSQ¬† Well, I'm glad we agree on moral absolutism. That's a good start. You talk about atomical "truths" which most humans see as obvious. Then you go on to say that we have a global basic notions about the world which basically all of us can agree on. But then you start to say that just because the vast majority agree on these notions doesn't mean the vast majority will be right about any moral issue. So, if by your logic, the humans across the entire world have similar experiences and reasoning capabilities just as you do. If over 99% of them come to the conclusion that something is okay to do, what makes that 99% wrong and the 1% right? At the end of the day everyone believes they are right, so the argument can't just be "I'm right because I believe I'm right", obviously there is some factor that brought the 99% percent of human beings on Earth to the same logical conclusion.


Now let's go over your logical reasoning for a second. You start by saying that people agree that it's better to maximize pleasure and minimize pain, I agree. As such, it would be wrong to unnecessarily beat your dog, or any animal for that matter. But then you make a leap to the logical conclusion that ergo eating animals is wrong, how so? Pain can be minimized in an animals death and no animal has to be beaten to obtain meat, so by your own logic meat is still okay so long as the animal was treated well and killed swiftly. Obviously, these factors do depend on where you get your meat but clearly you can see why others may come to a different logical conclusion that you have.
author: kalzoa

text:
First off, about your first paragraph. You say that if, as I say, most people agree on basic logical truths, then automatically they'll agree on all complex statements (regarding philosophy, ethics, etc.). First off, this is clearly empirically untrue because of the wide array of opinions lots of people have in most matters (even if in some matters, like veganism, this array is not so wide, and more polarized). But it's also fairly understandable how come it be that humans with common basic moral truths arrive at different conclusions. Firstly, because not all humans have similar experiences at all, and lots of them stray them further from objective reasoning, or just don't even allow them (or make it difficult to do so) the questioning of certain accepted statements. Secondly, because the brain is a really complex system, and different brains are very different. It's understandable that most brains arrive at the same basic logical truths, because as I said they're mostly based in the observation of the world (even if they can later be expressed as formal logic) and we all are familiar with them to achieve the simplest of tasks. Complex truths that are built upon them, on the contrary, usually have to pass through a lot of observations and steps to be achieved, and something can go wrong in them. If the brain were a perfect computer, a formal system, that wouldn't happen. But the brain is a neural network with way too many connections (and physicality) to assure perfection in reasoning. There are just lots of other things (prejudices, biases, or plain malfunction) that are going on in the brain and prevent a proper formal argument.
That's why one can hold as true certain basical truths, and simultaneously hold as true some more complex truth which contradicts them. That's called cognitive dissonance.
So I of course wasn't stating veganism is right "because I believe so".
I was arguing for veganism that eating animals contradicts the two basic truths I stated (maximize pleasure/minimize pain and that animals suffer and feel). And so, since these truths are accepted by most as obvious, and veganism on the other hand is a complex real issue, it's a strong argument that veganism is in fact correct, given it's the only option to follow these truths coherently.

Now: you tell me those two truths don't imply veganism. But consider: if the animal is suffering, that clearly isn't worth the taste of meat.
If, on the other hand, the animal is living a perfectly enjoyful and free life (which is NOT the case in more than 95% of the meat produced), killing him is still immoral, for you are depriving him of the pleasure he could have felt in the rest of his life (of course, if the animal is killed way before its life expectancy, which is always done in the industry). You may tell me, that by killin him painlessly we're just not inflicting any damage on it. But, though it clearly is better than killing him painfully, negating his life is clearly a moral prejudice, and a big one. You would never consider killing a person ethical just because it was done painlessly. And don't get me wrong: I'm not saying it's as bad to kill a nonhuman animal as to kill a person. I'm just using the example because the situation is analogous: a sentient being who wants to live will be negated the rest of his life.
As another way to put it, you could say that, no matter how well you've treated the animal BEFORE killing him, at the moment of killing him you're committing a moral inconsistency just the same. And even more: if you've cared about the animal's wellbeing enough to treat it well until then, what does you suddenly consider it acceptable to prejudice him, to negate him such joy that he would live.

And that's without entering in the matter that if we really had to care for all animals well, having them enjoyful and free, we'd quickly run out of space and resources. And on the other hand, a vegan diet utilizes 10 times less terrain (and some researchers even say 18 times less), and thus way less water, work, etc. and is thus way better for the environment. And also would allow to produce way more food, which would be good for humanity (I'm not saying the problem of people starving would be fixed by veganism, because we already produce 130% of the necessary food, but certainly more food would help).

But veganism is by far the most environmental, and ethical opinion.

Vegan is better for you (if you eat whole foods), it is much better for the environment (methane is actually 100 times worse than Co2 over a 25 year time scale because it degrades in the ionosphere), and then you don't need to murder animals (pigs are smarter than dogs). It will also lead to less obesity (think of the Co2 savings of not driving around 400 pound people), more fresh water (beef uses 33% of all available global fresh water) and fewer medical costs (14 trillion is lost yearly to preventable diseases related to meat consumption.)

Plant based foods are also delicious last night I had black bean and sweet potato tacos with coconut yogurt and pineapple salsa. My nut cheese and swiss chard salad is very very good too.

text: GM crops are almost universally a positive thing for consumers, but they have a boogeyman status. They produce larger, better tasting fruit and vegetables that are faster to mature and more durable to the elements with a longer shelf life. The issue is that small landowners in developing countries can't afford the added cost of the seeds and nobody will buy their regular produce when it's placed against a shiny GM product, but that has little to do with the environmental standpoint.

I also like to eat fish regularly. for breakfast and dinner I try to stick with cereal or sandwiches with some good hearty spreads, cheese and seasoning.

One day I might switch to full-blown vegetarian, but only when I can afford good fish and vegetables on a semi-regular basis

text: Look at the graph he showed, again. The Mediterranean diet is more than twice as wasteful as the vegan one. Even if everyone in the world went vegan, we'd still be over the planet's carrying capacity if we didn't change anything else, so everyone needs to be doing as much as they possibly can. Eating fish might help with climate change, but it won't help with the fact that scientists predict by 2050 we will exhaust all global fishing reserves. Bluefin tuna, yellow tail, albacore wild Atlantic salmon, pacific salad, Japanese eel and many other popular fish are endangered or threatened. text:
This is based on the assumption that people will suddenly care about the planet and are willing to change their diet in just that.
And then there's selfish people, admittedly, like me. If I see everyone changing to a vegan/planet friendly diet, I think: hey, so many are already doing the job, I don't need to change a thing. Yeeeah, there's probably more people than just me thinking like that. We should make meat more expensive, but it's difficult to enforce that in a liberal market economy.
We already have a very large lower income class. If they can't afford meat as often, they will find something else - something more friendly to the planet.

text:
I understand your angle, you don't want to come off as "extreme" however, how could you say that being a vegetarian is so close to vegan when cows in the dairy industry are confined for triple the time which allows for more Co2 emissions. Also, suggesting that we eat more fish and less cows has a huge effect on our oceans. The more fish we eat the quicker our oceans die, which is where 70% of our oxygen comes from. Add that to all the deforestation and wild fires that are going on today and we are doomed. A vegan lifestyle or plant based diet is the way to go. There isn't anything extreme about it, in fact it is extreme to be eating the way we have been eating for all these decades. 

If you really want to make a difference, start by reducing your intake of animal products with the goal of going plant based. You can save the planet but let's not tip toe around the subject like this video is. 
With love!

text: Amy thechubbylittlesatan - "FULL of preachy unapproachable ppl"? The problem with that statement is that you haven't met every single vegan to make that blanket assessment. If you did meet us all, you'd find most of us keep to ourselves. And since you haven't met the majority of Vegans (obviously how could you, we're quiet for the most part), your focus is on the few loud obnoxious ones who like to use social media to apply their activism. Their noise overshadows those of us who live by example rather than vocalize. And I'm not even mad at them. Bc I get why they're so passionate. It's a good cause & the opposition is horrifying. The extreme behavior of those vegans is reactionary & relative to the extreme behavior of the meat industry. They have a right to be upset. They wish to speak on behalf of the voiceless & powerless. As obnoxious as they are, their message is altruistic. I don't understand why anybody would allow the messenger to get in the way of accepting the validity of the message. Bc that's what it comes down to: WHAT'S being said, not WHO is saying it. And yea it is too bad that the select few ruin it for the majority, but that's still not an excuse for us to not assess the movement for its empowering message.

text: World starvation would not be rampant. Meat is actually the cause of world starvation bc livestock has lead to land desertification & soil depletion. Due to this issue, corporations have sought out land in 3rd world countries either by creating deforestation or via corporate land grabs. 91% of the amazonian deforestation is a result of animal agriculture. Corporate land grabs cause small local farms to be unable to compete. This causes much of these farmers to either sell their land or go bankrupt. The corporations gain control over food prices & drive them up so that they are able to export them to feed the livestock that will ultimately feed the wealthy West. 3rd world ppl lose jobs on farms & go into poverty. And the ones who can hold unto jobs can't afford the high prices driven by these corporations. Let's not forget our own economy stands to gain from cutting out meat since most of the industry takes its subsidies from our taxes. In regards to the fish, mercury is the least of our problems. Over 85% of fisheries are currently exploited & our oceans are expected to go extinct by 2048 if we continue at this rate. Our consumer demand leads to all kinds of problems I haven't even mentioned, the amount of fuel & water & land resources required is unsustainable. Deforestation leads to the displacement of indigenous ppl. Farmers in the US are trapped into horrible contracts & debt with the meat industry. Workers in meat factories deal with PTSD & food borne illnesses. Local citizens, who live by these farms, end up with illnesses as well. We're not just hurting the animals and our planet here, we're hurting humans! Our dollar is a vote for the kind of world we wish to live in. Be a responsible consumer. Be the change you wish to see.

author: I would have been your daddy

text: Problem is you're never going to convince enough people to cut down on meat to make a big impact. What we need is changes that happen automatically: making electric cars "cool" is a good example. Imagine if cultured meat suddenly became much cheaper than animal meat, and we could grow it using clean energy. Imagine if all the farming machines and food transportation was incentivized to switch to electric, if it became the cheaper option. Imagine if clean energy became so cheap that it became viable to grow food indoors in vertical farms, and we could grow most crops locally and without pesticides or herbicides. Asking people to make lifestyle changes has never scaled, except when the change is something they want anyway like "own a Tesla" or "buy cheaper food". There are plenty of good reasons to cut down on your meat consumption, but sadly it probably won't save the planet unless a majority does it. Imagine if all the meat in the world became infected with a debilitating pathogen...

text: It's more than just methane & carbon emissions. The amount of resources for Grass-fed is even higher than Grain-fed livestock. Let's not forget the deforestation, displacement of indigenous ppl, 3rd world starvation due to corporate land grabs & manipulation of food trade prices, wildlife extinction bc the cattle industry lobbies for hunting mandates that kill off land competitors, sealife extinction bc of the excessively exploited fishing & due to the fact that cattle are fed fish pellets. There's also the matter of our taxes paying all the subsidies for meat. If we cut out meat, it would create an economic boom for us bc we'd reduce the amount of taxes & allocate them towards infrastructure or allow us to generate consumer spending towards other industries.

lowlize if someone drinks milk for nutrients, then they do it for health reasons, if that's the case then they should know that the saturated fat and cholesterol, that is found in milk (aswell as all animal products), is the cause of heart disease and stroke. 

The oestrogen, and other hormones, found in milk is a strong factor for certain cancers, such as breast and prostate, as mammals are not designed to consume the breast milk of other species of mammal.

Countries with the highest consumption of milk are found to have the most cases of arthritis, osteoporosis and hip fractures. This is because consuming milk causes the blood to become acidic, to reverse the blood back to an alkaline state, the body leeches calcium out of the bones to use the phosphate to change the ph and then excretes the calcium. So the calcium in milk does not make our bones stronger

Let's not forget the deforestation, displacement of indigenous ppl, 3rd world starvation due to corporate land grabs & manipulation of food trade prices, wildlife extinction bc the cattle industry lobbies for hunting mandates that kill off land competitors, sealife extinction bc of the excessively exploited fishing & due to the fact that cattle are fed fish pellets. There's also the matter of our taxes paying all the subsidies for meat. If we cut out meat, it would create an economic boom for us bc we'd reduce the amount of taxes & allocate them towards infrastructure or allow us to generate consumer spending towards other industries.

text: While I'm all for vegans and vegetarians even though I eat meat, I honestly hate when vegans/vegetarians say this. You know exactly why most of the world eats meat: because it tastes good. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to understand that. Food is more than just a source of energy, for most people, there are memories attached to them. Certain meals remind them of home or of their family or of good childhood times that have been destroyed by the harsh reality of adulthood. To give those things up is HARD and vegans/vegetarians never seem to be empathetic with those that struggle to do so. That's one of the real reasons that many dislike vegans/vegetarians so much, they shun those that eat meat but never stop to consider that maybe they want to but are finding it really hard to give up something that holds a lot of sentimental value to them. And also, let's be honest, meat substitutes never taste as good as real meat.
author: Ally Koester

text:
Allison Koester i understand food is significant to people and can have sentimental meaning for people if it's a meal they associate with a memory. but it's still death. why is a meal that you have a sentimental attachment to more important that the actual life of the animal. all the suffering of the animal is in that plate of food as well as your memories. 

i understand if people find it difficult to eat less meat and go vegan if they have been thinking about it but just can't give up meals that they have had forever. it's a difficult transition but in reality there are vegan meals that are just as good nutritionally and taste wise and also you don't really need to taste a meal to remember that you had it as a child and reminisce about how things were back then or something.
author: flower

text: I'm not saying that it actually IS more important, giving up meat is a wonderful thing. What I'm trying to say is that someone might want to give up meat but struggle with it because it's hard to give up those memories. I think that the best way to give up meat would be through a slow and tedious yet gentle process with lots of encouragement along the way.

text:
The biggest change you could do in your diet is to make sure you're not consuming more than 4oz of meat per day. That amount is enough to keep you well fed and strong, and also keep your greenhouse emissions under control. Just that would be a huge improvement by itself. 

Another step forward would be to understand what makes meat so satisfying for you personally and try to emulate that with other types of foods. For me, for example, it's about the fullness, meat is mostly protein which is very filling, so sometimes I just eat a salad with mozzarella cheese (high in protein and fats). The same goes for fish, especially one that doesn't stink, chicken, and tofu.

It takes a while to find what you like but after a while it becomes part of your diet, not just a fancy replacement for beef. Being sensible in your food choices isn't about propaganda, it's about going away with our previously learned food habits, which can be very tough. That is why post people don't do it.

p.s. They mentioned this about the mediterranean diet, but it might have slipped. It contains a lot of olive oil. When my mom makes a sallad, there's a ton of olive oil in it. And there's a good reason for it -- fats are tasty, very high in energy, and satiating, so they have the same effect as proteins. However, that doesn't go well with our Western teaching about the evil of fats. Not all fats are born equal, though; olive oil can be safely consumed in much larger quantities.

text:
to everybody saying that veganism is better, we get it. veganism does save resources such as water and reduce CO2 emissions.

However, veganism also takes away land from ecosystems, like forests and woods in which animals like goats are bred in. It consumes much more land because much more crops are consumed per day than meat (you probably eat around 200% more grain than chicken a day).

Not only that, but many vegans consume market oil, which is developed from animal fat; animal fats are also used industrially very commonly. To take away these animal fats would require new replacements to be developed, which is costly and isnt always doable.

Veganism has its arguments, and it has its counterarguments. If somebody doesn't want to be vegan or does, it's their choice, and you have no right to enforce what you don't even know is truly beneficial to the world on somebody else.

Veganism is also not necessarily healthier. High protein, mineral and Carbohydrate consumption combined with high activity and physical stress builds muscle and develops the immune system much faster and more efficiently than vegetarianism. Many male athletes consume a lot of meat for a reason. That being said, without that high physical stress, the protein and minerals go out of your system and you just gain fat, in which case veganism is much better.
author: Jason Peng

text: Wow people really will argue the most ridiculous things to try to justify their meat consumption. Clazza, as OP mentioned just because animals do something in the wild does not at all mean it is ethical for humans to do that. We have a CHOICE to eat meat. People choose to eat meat because it tastes good even though it causes immense suffering to millions of factory farmed animals and is terrible for the planet. Wild animals do not have this choice. Also for people saying plants feel pain, do you really think that pain is comparable to what intelligent animals like pigs or cows feel? Many plants evolved to have part of themselves be eaten. Many flowering plants would not reproduce if animals didn't eat their fruit and spread their seeds. And to Jason Peng, veganism does require much less land than a traditional American omnivorous diet. First of all, livestock, especially grazing animals, require lots of land. And secondly, you have to feed the animals something. If humans ate what we fed to animals, that would be much more efficient and use much less land. Energy is lost at each trophic level, so when we eat a chicken that ate some grain, we gain 90% less energy than if we just ate all the grain the chicken ate.

text:
to everybody saying that veganism is better, we get it. veganism does save resources such as water and reduce CO2 emissions.

However, veganism also takes away land from ecosystems, like forests and woods in which animals like goats are bred in. It consumes much more land because much more crops are consumed per day than meat (you probably eat around 200% more grain than chicken a day).

Not only that, but many vegans consume market oil, which is developed from animal fat; animal fats are also used industrially very commonly. To take away these animal fats would require new replacements to be developed, which is costly and isnt always doable.

Veganism has its arguments, and it has its counterarguments. If somebody doesn't want to be vegan or does, it's their choice, and you have no right to enforce what you don't even know is truly beneficial to the world on somebody else.

text:
Honest Lad That's kind of a straw man. Claiming you support the fight against climate change, and then turning a blind eye to a major cause of greenhouse gas emissions, and environmental destruction is hypocritical. That's also a black and white fallacy. It's unrealistic to expect someone to not breathe. 
Even if the world switches to green power tomorrow, they will still be tearing down the rainforest to make way for animal feed, overfishing will still be taking place, there will still be copious amounts of cattle sewage running into the ocean and causing dead spots,  and methane will still be released from the cattle.  I really recommend looking into this at the very least. It doesn't mean you have to become vegan, but if everyone reduced the amount of meat they ate, it would make a huge difference.

text:
to everybody saying that veganism is better, we get it. veganism does save resources such as water and reduce CO2 emissions.

However, veganism also takes away land from ecosystems, like forests and woods in which animals like goats are bred in. It consumes much more land because much more crops are consumed per day than meat (you probably eat around 200% more grain than chicken a day).

Not only that, but many vegans consume market oil, which is developed from animal fat; animal fats are also used industrially very commonly. To take away these animal fats would require new replacements to be developed, which is costly and isnt always doable.

Veganism has its arguments, and it has its counterarguments. If somebody doesn't want to be vegan or does, it's their choice, and you have no right to enforce what you don't even know is truly beneficial to the world on somebody else.

Veganism is also not necessarily healthier. High protein, mineral and Carbohydrate consumption combined with high activity and physical stress builds muscle and develops the immune system much faster and more efficiently than vegetarianism. Many male athletes consume a lot of meat for a reason. That being said, without that high physical stress, the protein and minerals go out of your system and you just gain fat, in which case veganism is much better.

text:
Jason Peng I'm sorry but your info does not match with the scientific consensus.

As the video states, the amount of grain we feed animals could feed 3.5 billion people instead. Cows need a lot more grain to eat than humans and we may need to eat more grain than a chicken but there's about 50billion chickens on earth so they consume a lot of grain too, along with all other livestock.

Considering Patrick baboumian is a power lifting world record holder and vegan, and Kendrick Ferris was the lone American weightlifter who qualified for the 2016 Olympics, setting a U.S record, and vegan. It shows building muscle and strength is at the very least, no more difficult on a vegan diet compared to an omnivorous diet.

Veganism may have counterarguments but they are far outweighed and become negligible by the pro arguments

text:
He didn't do much more than mention that there are better ways to produce beef than the ways we normally do today. Properly ranged beef can actually sequester carbon in the soil and make use of natural forage rather than using grains which require extra water and fertilizer and pesticides and herbicides etc. 

When we do grow grain, we should eat that ourselves and not feed it to animals due to the enormous carbon footprint that results. But eating animals that have fed on grasses and forbs and ranged from one field to another rather than just standing around in lots denuding the land of all foliage will have a much greater effect on Global Warming than just going vegan will. That part is never really figured into these sorts of calculations.

text: iwasintheshower "Yes he said that- but if you do research on your own..." Yes, let's all trust the Internet vegan and one or two 'lifestyle guru' blog posts, instead of trusting the mass amounts of research done by qualified scientists with one of the best universities in the world, who have spent their lives researching and conducting experiments and models on this topic. text:
to everybody saying that veganism is better, we get it. veganism does save resources such as water and reduce CO2 emissions.

However, veganism also takes away land from ecosystems, like forests and woods in which animals like goats are bred in. It consumes much more land because much more crops are consumed per day than meat (you probably eat around 200% more grain than chicken a day).

Not only that, but many vegans consume market oil, which is developed from animal fat; animal fats are also used industrially very commonly. To take away these animal fats would require new replacements to be developed, which is costly and isnt always doable.

Veganism has its arguments, and it has its counterarguments. If somebody doesn't want to be vegan or does, it's their choice, and you have no right to enforce what you don't even know is truly beneficial to the world on somebody else.

author: Crispman 777

text:
Noah Simmons,

Businesses have to take risks sometimes to get an edge over the competition. Just because there isn't a guarantee of success doesn't mean the risk isn't worth taking. Sometimes being the first to take an actually good enough product to market is all it takes to become very successful. It's generally easier and cheaper to grow and process plants into various foods than meat. Maybe it will require a lot of R&D, but a good meat substitute that is cheaper than meat is not far from possible. A lot more work than you seem to know of has already been done. You're thinking "What would it be like if some startup started from scratch now" and "what would it be like immediately after they did it" as if that's always how it will be. If they can get fast food restaurants to use the cheaper meat substitute, they could make a lot of money. If it's easy for busy parents to feed their kids with and the kids don't complain about it, there's a market too.

Your example with the bacon and the carrot simply doesn't work because it implies that a bacon substitute could only taste like carrot or some other vegetable. Those don't even have the nutrients that are necessary for a meat replacement. Bacon is not something you should eat frequently though, so I do not think it would be worth the effort of replacing. When you eat bacon, you should know you're eating junk food. Pork and steak are the 2 most in need of a good substitute and certainly not as difficult as bacon. Meat does have a taste, but not much of one and it's easy to overpower. Burgers you buy from McDonalds don't really taste that much like beef because they have so much added to them.

author: Ofelia

text:
nexus1g I am reading what you're posting. It just happens that I don't agree with you. You keep telling us your opinion as if it were fact, even when you're completely wrong. For example, vegans can definitely get enough B12, as there are plenty of B12-fortified plant-based milk alternatives or supplements. I mean, you realize that the only reason meat provides enough B12 is because livestock often gets B12 supplements, right? Your argument about the lack of essential amino acids is a fantasy as well, as beans, seeds, nuts, greens, fruits, grains, etc., are all very good sources of all different amino acids. 

Honestly, you sound like someone who once heard someone say vegans don't get enough B12 or amino acids, and decided they were telling the truth without doing your own research. Like, it's as easy as just googling "vegan B12" or "vegan amino acids" and you'll be met with a ton of information on the subjects.

Honest Lad in my experience meat is more expensive, Ive eaten meat in the past and been a vegetarian for 2 years. As someone that‚Äôs tried both diets I certainly prefer to eat a vegetarian diet because 1. I‚Äôve found it much cheaper
2. I feel less tired, get less headaches, and generally have more energy
3. I look forwards to eating more, for less price the food I‚Äôm eating now tastes fresher and tastier imo, and I feel good afterwards and no longer bloat after eating lots.

Another point is that meat can be quite cheap in the store, but agriculture is expensive to upkeep a lot of taxpayers money goes into it, so a portion of tax we pay goes into the expenses of meat production
